{{other people|Chris Williams}} {{Infobox person | name = Chris Williams | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|40|2009|02|25}}{{cite news|last=Knelman|first=Martin|title=Bolt from blue took Canadian to Oscars|url=https://www.thestar.com/sponsored_sections/2009/02/25/bolt_from_blue_took_canadian_to_oscars.html|accessdate=December 24, 2013|newspaper=The Star|date=February 25, 2009}} | birth_place = [[Missouri]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | yearsactive = 1998–present | spouse = | occupation = [[Animator]], [[film director]], [[screenwriter]] | employer = [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] | notable_works = ''[[Glago's Guest]]''
''[[Bolt (2008 film)|Bolt]]''
''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]''
''[[Moana (2016 film)|Moana]]'' | alma_mater = [[University of Waterloo]]
[[Sheridan College]] | homepage = }} '''Chris Williams''' (born c. 1968/1969) is a [[Canadian Americans|Canadian American]] [[animator]], [[film director]] and [[screenwriter]] at [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]]. He directed the short film ''[[Glago's Guest]]'' and co-directed ''[[Bolt (2008 film)|Bolt]]'', which was nominated for the Oscar for Best Animated Feature in 2009; ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]'', which won the [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] for Best Animated Feature in 2015 and ''[[Moana (2016 film)|Moana]],'' which was nominated for two Oscars for Best Animated Feature and Best Original Song in 2016. ==Early life== Williams was born in [[Missouri]] and spent the first 25 years of his life in [[Waterloo, Ontario]], Canada, where his father was the Director of Counselling Services at the [[University of Waterloo]]. Williams graduated from the University of Waterloo with a degree in Fine Arts{{cite web|title=University of Waterloo alumnus wins Oscar for Big Hero 6|url=https://uwaterloo.ca/stories/university-waterloo-alumnus-wins-oscar-big-hero-6|website=Waterloo Stories|publisher=University of Waterloo}} and then enrolled in the animation program at [[Sheridan College]], Oakville, Ontario. Upon graduation from Sheridan, he was recruited by Disney and moved to Los Angeles. ==Career== Williams previously worked in the story department for ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'' (1998), ''[[The Emperor's New Groove]]'' (2000), and ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'' (2013), in which he also voiced the character Oaken. In February 2007, it was announced he would direct ''American Dog'',{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2007/digital/news/toy-story-sequel-set-1117959040/ | title='Toy Story' sequel set | last=Fritz | first=Ben | publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' | date=February 8, 2007 | accessdate=December 9, 2014}} which was re-titled ''[[Bolt (2008 film)|Bolt]]'' (2008), and was later joined by [[Byron Howard]], both of them replaced [[Chris Sanders (director)|Chris Sanders]] who was the original director.{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/bolt-teaser-poster-a-look-back-at-american-dog/ | title=Bolt Teaser Poster; A Look Back at American Dog | last=Sciretta | first=Peter | publisher=''[[/Film]]'' | date=June 20, 2008 | accessdate=December 9, 2014}} In July 2010, it was reported by various sources that Williams would direct ''King of the Elves'' based on the story by [[Philip K. Dick]].{{cite web|title=King of the Elves being reworked; Disney plans far ahead|url=http://filmonic.com/king-of-the-elves-being-reworked-disney-plans-far-ahead|accessdate=December 24, 2011|newspaper=Filmonic|date=August 6, 2010}}{{cite news | last=Graser | first=Marc | last2=Sneider | first2=Jeff | url=https://variety.com/2011/film/news/disney-revives-king-of-the-elves-toon-1118039315/ | title=Disney revives 'King of the Elves' toon | publisher=''Variety'' | date=June 29, 2011 | accessdate=June 30, 2011}}{{cite news| title=Disney Sets HORRIBLE BOSSES Scribe to Pen KING OF THE ELVES | last=Chitwood | first=Adam | url=http://collider.com/king-of-the-elves-michael-markowitz-disney/ | work=Collider | date=June 29, 2011 | accessdate=December 9, 2014}} However, in December 2013, it was revealed that Williams had joined another Walt Disney Animation film, ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]'', as a co-director inspired by the [[Marvel Comics]] of [[Big Hero 6 (comics)|the same name]]. ==Filmography== * ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'' (1998) (writer: story) * ''[[The Emperor's New Groove]]'' (2000) (story, along with [[Mark Dindal]]) * ''[[Lilo & Stitch]]'' (2002) (story supervisor) * ''[[Brother Bear]]'' (2003) (additional story material, writer) * ''[[Chicken Little (2005 film)|Chicken Little]]'' (2005) (story artist) * ''[[Meet the Robinsons]]'' (2007) (additional story artist) * ''[[Glago's Guest]]'' (2008) (director) * ''[[Tinker Bell (film)|Tinker Bell]]'' (2008) (story artist, writer) * ''[[Bolt (2008 film)|Bolt]]'' (2008) (director with [[Byron Howard]], writer, additional voices) * ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'' (2013) (story artist, voice of Oaken) * ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]'' (2014) (director with [[Don Hall (filmmaker)|Don Hall]]){{cite news|last=Giardina|first=Carolyn|title=Chris Williams To Co-Direct Disney Animation's 'Big Hero 6' With Don Hall|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/chris-williams-direct-disney-animation-668066|accessdate=December 31, 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=December 31, 2013}} * ''[[Frozen Fever]]'' (2015) (voice of Oaken) * ''[[Moana (2016 film)|Moana]]'' (2016) (co-director with Don Hall, story){{cite web|last1=Sciretta|first1=Peter|title=Disney Animation's Big Announcement Coming Tomorrow, Here's What It Could Be|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/disney-animations-big-announcement/|publisher=/Film|accessdate=August 21, 2016|date=June 29, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Moana (Trailer H)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/moana-filmtrailer-4|publisher=British Board of Film Classification|accessdate=September 27, 2016}} * ''[[Frozen (franchise)#Frozen: Northern Lights|LEGO Frozen: Northern Lights]]'' (2016) (voice of Oaken) * ''[[Olaf's Frozen Adventure]]'' (2017) (voice of Oaken) * ''[[Ralph Breaks the Internet]]'' (2018) (executive producer with [[Jennifer Lee (filmmaker)|Jennifer Lee]] and [[John Lasseter]]) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|0930261|Chris Williams}} {{Academy Award for Best Animated Feature}} revision.text:
{{Critical pedagogy}} '''Critical pedagogy''' is a [[philosophy of education]] and [[social movement]] that has developed and applied concepts from [[critical theory]] and related traditions to the field of [[education]] and the study of culture.{{cite book|last1=Kincheloe|first1=Joe|last2=Steinburg|first2=Shirley|year=1997|title=Changing Multiculturalism|publisher=Open University Press|location=[[Bristol, PA]]|page=24|quote="Critical pedagogy is the term used to describe what emerges when critical theory encounters education"}} Advocates of critical pedagogy view teaching as an inherently [[political]] act, reject the neutrality of knowledge, and insist that issues of [[social justice]] and [[democracy]] itself are not distinct from acts of [[teaching]] and [[learning]].Giroux, H., 2007. Utopian thinking in dangerous times: Critical pedagogy and the project of educated hope. Utopian pedagogy: Radical experiments against neoliberal globalization, pp.25-42. The goal of critical pedagogy is [[emancipation]] from [[oppression]] through an awakening of the [[critical consciousness]], based on the [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] term ''[[conscientização]]''. When achieved, critical consciousness encourages individuals to effect change in their world through [[Social criticism|social critique]] and [[Activism|political action]]. == Background == The concept of critical pedagogy can be traced back to [[Paulo Freire]]'s best-known 1968 work, ''[[The Pedagogy of the Oppressed]]''. Freire, a professor of [[history]] and the [[philosophy of education]] at the [[University of Recife]] in Brazil, sought in this and other works to develop a philosophy of adult education that demonstrated a solidarity with the poor in their common struggle to survive by engaging them in a dialogue of greater awareness and analysis. Although his family had suffered loss and hunger during the [[Great Depression]], the poor viewed him and his formerly middle-class family "as people from another world who happened to fall accidentally into their world".{{Cite book|title=Pedagogy of the Oppressed|last=Freire|first=Paulo|publisher=The Continuum International Publishing Group Inc.|year=2009|isbn=978-0-8264-1276-8|location=New York, NY|pages=|quote=|via=}} His intimate discovery of class and their borders "led, invariably, to Freire's radical rejection of a class-based society". The influential works of [[Paulo Freire|Freire]] made him arguably the most celebrated critical educator. He seldom used the term "critical pedagogy" himself when describing this philosophy. His initial focus targeted adult [[literacy]] projects in Brazil and later was adapted to deal with a wide range of social and educational issues. Freire's pedagogy revolved around an anti-authoritarian and interactive approach aimed to examine issues of relational power for students and workers. The center of the curriculum used the fundamental goal based on social and political critiques of everyday life. Freire's praxis required implementation of a range of educational practices and processes with the goal of creating not only a better learning environment but also a better world. Freire himself maintained that this was not merely an educational technique but a way of living in our educative practice. Freire endorses students' ability to think critically about their education situation; this way of thinking is thought by practitioners of critical pedagogy to allow them to "recognize connections between their individual problems and experiences and the social contexts in which they are embedded".{{cite web | url = http://mingo.info-science.uiowa.edu/~stevens/critped/page1.htm | title = Critical Pedagogy on the Web | archive-url = https://archive.is/20030715084613/http://mingo.info-science.uiowa.edu/~stevens/critped/page1.htm | archive-date = 2003-07-15 | access-date = 2017-04-12 | deadurl = yes | df = }} Realizing one's consciousness ("[[Critical consciousness|conscientization]]", "''conscientização"'') is then a needed first step of "[[Praxis (process)|praxis]]", which is defined as the power and know-how to take action against oppression while stressing the importance of liberating education. "Praxis involves engaging in a cycle of theory, application, evaluation, reflection, and then back to theory. Social transformation is the product of praxis at the collective level." Critical pedagogue [[Ira Shor]], who was mentored by and worked closely with Freire from 1980 until Freire's death in 1997,{{Cite web|url=http://www.english.csi.cuny.edu/ira_shor.html|title=Ira Shor|website=English Department|access-date=2016-11-22}} defines critical pedagogy as: {{quote|Habits of thought, reading, writing, and speaking which go beneath surface meaning, first impressions, dominant myths, official'' ''pronouncements, traditional clichés, received wisdom, and mere opinions, to understand the deep meaning, root causes, social'' ''context, ideology, and personal consequences of any action, event, object, process, organization, experience, text, subject'' ''matter, policy, mass media, or discourse. (''Empowering Education'', 129)}} Critical pedagogy explores the dialogic relationships between teaching and learning. Its proponents claim that it is a continuous process of what they call "unlearning", "learning", and "relearning", "reflection", "evaluation", and the effect that these actions have on the students, in particular students whom they believe have been historically and continue to be disenfranchised by what they call "traditional schooling". {{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} The educational philosophy has since been developed by [[Henry Giroux]] and others since the 1980s as a [[praxis (process)|praxis]]-oriented "educational movement, guided by passion and principle, to help students develop [[critical consciousness|a consciousness]] of freedom, recognize authoritarian tendencies, and connect knowledge to power and the ability to take constructive action".Giroux, H. (October 27, 2010) "Lessons From Paulo Freire", ''[[Chronicle of Higher Education]].'' Retrieved 10/20/10. Freire wrote the introduction to his 1988 work, ''Teachers as Intellectuals: Toward a Critical Pedagogy of Learning.'' Another leading critical pedagogy theorist who Freire called his "intellectual cousin",{{Cite web|url=https://philcsc.wordpress.com/2016/01/09/foreword-to-peter-mclarens-pedagogy-of-insurrection/|title=Foreword to Peter McLaren's Pedagogy of Insurrection|last=philcsc|date=2016-01-09|website=philcsc.wordpress.com|access-date=2016-11-23}} [[Peter McLaren]], wrote the foreword. McLaren and Giroux co-edited one book on critical pedagogy and co-authored another in the 1990s. Among its other leading figures in no particular order are [[bell hooks]] (Gloria Jean Watkins), [[Joe L. Kincheloe]], Patti Lather, [[Antonia Darder]], [[Gloria Ladson-Billings]], [[Peter McLaren]], [[Joe L. Kincheloe]], [[Khen Lampert]], [[Howard Zinn]], [[Donaldo Macedo]], Sandy Grande, [[Michael Apple]], and Stephanie Ledesma. Educationalists including [[Jonathan Kozol]] and [[Parker Palmer]] are sometimes included in this category. Other critical pedagogues known more for their [[Anti-schooling activism|Anti-schooling,]] [[unschooling]], or [[deschooling]] perspectives include [[Ivan Illich]], [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]], [[Ira Shor]], [[John Taylor Gatto]], and [[Matt Hern]]. Critical pedagogy has several other strands and foundations.Kincheloe, Joe (2008) Critical Pedagogy Primer. New York: Peter Lang [[Postmodern]], [[anti-racist]], [[feminist]], [[postcolonial]], and [[queer]] theories all play a role in further expanding and enriching Freire's original ideas about a critical pedagogy, shifting its main focus on social class to include issues pertaining to [[religion]], [[military rank|military identification]], [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[gender]], [[sexual orientation|sexuality]], [[nationality]], [[ethnicity]], and age. Much of the work also draws on [[anarchism]], [[György Lukács]], [[Wilhelm Reich]], [[postcolonialism]], and the discourse theories of [[Edward Said]], [[Antonio Gramsci]], [[Gilles Deleuze]] ([[rhizomatic learning]]) and [[Michel Foucault]]. ''[[Radical Teacher]]'' is a magazine dedicated to critical pedagogy and issues of interest to critical educators. Many contemporary critical pedagogues have embraced [[Postmodern philosophy|Postmodern]], [[non-essentialism|anti-essentialist]] perspectives of the individual, of language, and of power, "while at the same time retaining the [[Paulo Freire|Freirean]] emphasis on critique, disrupting oppressive regimes of power/knowledge, and social change". ==Developments== Like [[critical theory]] itself, the field of critical pedagogy continues to evolve. Contemporary critical educators, such as [[bell hooks]] and [[Peter McLaren]], discuss in their criticisms the influence of many varied concerns, institutions, and social structures, "including globalization, the mass media, and race/spiritual relations", while citing reasons for resisting the possibilities to change. McLaren has developed a social movement based version of critical pedagogy that he calls revolutionary critical pedagogy, emphasizing critical pedagogy as a social movement for the creation of a democratic socialist alternative to capitalism.{{cite web | url=http://pages.gseis.ucla.edu/faculty/mclaren/ | title=Peter McLaren, PhD | Professor, Distinguished Professor in Critical Studies; Co-Director, the Paulo Freire Democratic Project and International Ambassador for Global Ethics and Social Justice}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.hamptoninstitution.org/peter-mclaren-interview.html#.WDTetvkrLD4|title=Revolutionary Critical Pedagogy and the Struggle against Capital Today: An Interview with Peter McLaren I The Hampton Institute|website=www.hamptoninstitution.org|access-date=2016-11-23}} [[Joe L. Kincheloe]] and Shirley R. Steinberg have created the Paulo and Nita Freire Project for International Critical Pedagogy at [[McGill University|McGill]] University.{{cite web|url=http://www.freireproject.org/|title=Freire Project - Critical Cultural, Community, and Media Activism|author=|date=|website=www.freireproject.org}} In line with Kincheloe and Steinberg's contributions to critical pedagogy, the project attempts to move the field to the next phase of its evolution. In this second phase, critical pedagogy seeks to become a worldwide, decolonizing movement dedicated to listening to and learning from diverse [[discourse]]s of people from around the planet. Kincheloe and Steinberg also embrace Indigenous knowledges in education as a way to expand critical pedagogy and to question educational hegemony. Joe L. Kincheloe, in expanding on the Freire's notion that a pursuit of social change alone could promote anti-intellectualism, promotes a more balanced approach to education than postmodernists.{{Quote|text=We cannot simply attempt to cultivate the intellect without changing the unjust social context in which such minds operate. Critical educators cannot just work to change the social order without helping to educate a knowledgeable and skillful group of students. Creating a just, progressive, creative, and democratic society demands both dimensions of this pedagogical progress.|sign=|source=}} One of the major texts taking up the intersection between critical pedagogy and Indigenous knowledge(s) is Sandy Grande's, ''Red Pedagogy: Native American Social and Political Thought'' (Rowman and Littlefield, 2004). In agreement with this perspective, Four Arrows, aka Don Trent Jacobs, challenges the anthropocentrism of critical pedagogy and writes that to achieve its transformative goals there are other differences between Western and Indigenous worldview that must be considered.Kincheloe, J. & Steinberg, S. (2008) Indigenous Knowledges in Education: Complexities, Dangers, and Profound Benefits in Ed Denzin, N. Handbook of Critical and Indigenous MethodologiesFour Arrows (2011) Differing Worldviews: Two Scholars Argue Cooperatively about Justice Education (Sense) Approaching the intersection of Indigenous perspectives and pedagogy from another perspective, [[critical pedagogy of place]] examines the impacts of place. === In the classroom === [[Ira Shor]], a professor at the [[City University of New York]], provides for an example of how critical pedagogy is used in the classroom. He develops these themes in looking at the use of Freirean teaching methods in the context of the everyday life of classrooms, in particular, institutional settings. He suggests that the whole curriculum of the classroom must be re-examined and reconstructed. He favors a change of role of the student from object to active, critical subject. In doing so, he suggests that students undergo a struggle for ownership of themselves. He states that students have previously been lulled into a sense of complacency by the circumstances of everyday life and that through the processes of the classroom, they can begin to envision and strive for something different for themselves. Of course, achieving such a goal is not automatic nor easy, as he suggests that the role of the teacher is critical to this process. Students need to be helped by teachers to separate themselves from unconditional acceptance of the conditions of their own existence. Once this separation is achieved, then students may be prepared for critical re-entry into an examination of everyday life. In a classroom environment that achieves such liberating intent, one of the potential outcomes is that the students themselves assume more responsibility for the class. Power is thus distributed amongst the group and the role of the teacher becomes much more mobile, not to mention more challenging. This encourages the growth of each student's intellectual character rather than a mere "mimicry of the professorial style."Shor, I. (1980). Critical Teaching and Everyday Life. Boston, Massachusetts: South End Press. Teachers, however, do not simply abdicate their authority in a [[Student-centred learning|student-centred]] classroom. In the later years of his life, Freire grew increasingly concerned with what he felt was a major misinterpretation of his work and insisted that teachers cannot deny their position of authority. {{Quote|text=Critical teachers, therefore, must admit that they are in a position of authority and then demonstrate that authority in their actions in supports of students... [A]s teachers relinquish the authority of truth providers, they assume the mature authority of facilitators of student inquiry and problem-solving. In relation to such teacher authority, students gain their freedom--they gain the ability to become self-directed human beings capable of producing their own knowledge.|sign=[[Joe L. Kincheloe]]|source=[[Critical Pedagogy Primer]] p. 17}} And due to the student-centeredness that critical pedagogy insists upon, there are inherent conflicts associated with the "large collections of top-down content standards in their disciplines". Critical pedagogy advocates insist that teachers themselves are vital to the discussion about [[Standards-based education reform in the United States]] because a pedagogy that requires a student to learn or a teacher to teach externally imposed information exemplifies the [[banking model of education]] outlined by Freire where the structures of knowledge are left unexamined. To the critical pedagogue, the teaching act must incorporate social critique alongside the cultivation of intellect. [[Joe L. Kincheloe]] argues that this is in direct opposition to the [[Epistemology|epistemological]] concept of [[positivism]], where "social actions should proceed with law-like predictability". In this philosophy, a teacher and their students would be served by [[Standards-based education reform in the United States|Standards-based education]] where there is "only be one correct way to teach" as "[e]veryone is assumed to be the same regardless of race, class, or gender". [[Donald Schön]]'s concept of "indeterminate zones of practice" illustrates how any practice, especially ones with human subjects at their center, are infinitely complex and highly contested, which amplify the critical pedagogue's unwillingness to apply universal practices.{{Cite journal|last=Schon|first=Donald, A.|year=1995|title=The new scholarship requires a new epistemology|url=|journal=Change|volume=27|pages=|via=}} Furthermore, [[bell hooks]], who is greatly influenced by Freire, points out the importance of engaged pedagogy and the responsibility that teachers, as well as students, must have in the classroom:{{cite web|url=http://www.infed.org/thinkers/hooks.htm|title=bell hooks on education|author=|date=28 January 2013|website=infed.org}} {{quote|Teachers must be aware of themselves as practitioners and as human beings if they wish to teach students in a non-threatening, anti-discriminatory way. Self-actualisation should be the goal of the teacher as well as the students.}} == Resistance from students == Students sometimes resist critical pedagogy. Student resistance to critical pedagogy can be attributed to a variety of reasons. Student objections may be due to ideological reasons, religious or moral convictions, fear of criticism, or discomfort with controversial issues. Kristen Seas argues: "Resistance in this context thus occurs when students are asked to shift not only their perspectives, but also their subjectivities as they accept or reject assumptions that contribute to the pedagogical arguments being constructed."{{Cite journal|last=Seas|first=Kristen|year=2006|title=Enthymematic Rhetoric and Student Resistance to Critical Pedagogies|jstor=20176747|journal=Rhetoric Review|volume=(25) 4|pages=429}} Karen Kopelson asserts that resistance to new information or [[Ideology|ideologies]], introduced in the classroom, is a natural response to persuasive messages that are unfamiliar.
Resistance is often, at the least, understandably protective: As anyone who can remember her or his own first uneasy encounters with particularly challenging new theories or theorists can attest, resistance serves to shield us from uncomfortable shifts or all-out upheavals in perception and understanding-shifts in perception which, if honored, force us to inhabit the world in fundamentally new and different ways.{{Cite journal|last=Kopelson|first=Karen|year=2003|title=Rhetoric on the edge of cunning: Or, the performance of neutrality (re) considered as a composition pedagogy for student resistance|jstor=3594203|journal=College Composition and Communication|volume=|pages=119|via=}}
Kristen Seas further explains: "Students [often] reject the teacher's message because they see it as coercive, they do not agree with it, or they feel excluded by it." Karen Kopelson concludes "that many if not most students come to the university in order to gain access to and eventual enfranchisement in 'the establishment,' not to critique and reject its privileges." To overcome student resistance to critical pedagogy, teachers must enact strategic measures to help their students negotiate controversial topics. == Critical pedagogy of teaching == The rapidly changing demographics of the classroom in the [[United States]] has resulted in an unprecedented amount of [[linguistic]] and [[cultural]] diversity. In order to respond to these changes, advocates of critical pedagogy call into question the focus on practical skills of teacher credential programs. "[T]his practical focus far too often occurs without examining teachers' own assumptions, values, and beliefs and how this ideological posture informs, often unconsciously, their perceptions and actions when working with linguistic-minority and other politically, socially, and economically subordinated students."{{Cite journal|last=Bartolomé|first=Lilia|year=2004|title=Critical Pedagogy and Teacher Education: Radicalizing Prospective Teachers|url=http://www.teqjournal.org/backvols/2004/31_1/bartoleme.pmd.pdf|journal=Teacher Education Quarterly|volume=Winter|pages=97–122|via=teqjournal}} As teaching is considered an inherently political act to the critical pedagogue, a more critical element of teacher education becomes addressing implicit biases (also known as [[implicit cognition]] or implicit stereotypes) that can subconsciously affect a teacher's perception of a student's ability to learn.{{Cite web|url=http://kirwaninstitute.osu.edu/research/understanding-implicit-bias/|title=Understanding Implicit Bias|website=kirwaninstitute.osu.edu|access-date=2016-11-23}} Advocates of critical pedagogy insist that teachers, then, must become learners alongside their students, as well as students ''of'' their students. They must become experts beyond their field of [[knowledge]], and immerse themselves in the [[culture]], customs, and lived experiences of the students they aim to teach. == History == During South African [[apartheid]], legal [[racialization]] implemented by the regime drove members of the radical [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] Teachers' League of South Africa to employ critical pedagogy with a focus on nonracialism in Cape Town schools and prisons. Teachers collaborated loosely to subvert the racist curriculum and encourage critical examination of religious, military, political, and social circumstances in terms of spirit-friendly, humanist, and democratic ideologies. The efforts of such teachers are credited with having bolstered student resistance and activism.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} == Criticism == Philosopher [[John Searle]] characterizes the goal of Giroux's form of critical pedagogy "to create political radicals", thus highlighting the antagonistic moral and political grounds of the ideals of citizenship and "public wisdom."Searle, John. (1990) ''The Storm Over the University'', ''The New York Review of Books'', December 6, 1990. These varying moral perspectives of what is "right" are to be found in what [[John Dewey]]Dewey, John. (1938). Experience and Education. has referred to as the tensions between traditional and [[progressive education]]. Searle argues that critical pedagogy's objections to the [[Western canon]] are misplaced and/or disingenuous:
Precisely by inculcating a critical attitude, the "canon" served to demythologize the conventional pieties of the American bourgeoisie and provided the student with a perspective from which to critically analyze American culture and institutions. Ironically, the same tradition is now regarded as oppressive. The texts once served an unmasking function; now we are told that it is the texts which must be unmasked.
Maxine Hairston takes a hard line against critical pedagogy in the first year college composition classroom and argues, "everywhere I turn I find composition faculty, both leaders in the profession and new voices, asserting that they have not only the right, but the duty, to put ideology and radical politics at the center of their teaching."{{Cite journal|last=Hairston|first=Maxine|year=1992|title=Diversity, ideology, and teaching writing.|journal=College Composition and Communication|volume=43 |issue=2|pages=179–193|doi=10.2307/357563|jstor=357563}} Hairston further confers,
When classes focus on complex issues such as racial discrimination, economic injustices, and inequities of class and gender, they should be taught by qualified faculty who have the depth of information and historical competence that such critical social issues warrant. Our society's deep and tangled cultural conflicts can neither be explained nor resolved by simplistic ideological formulas.
Sharon O'Dair (2003) says that today compositionists "focus [...] almost exclusively on ideological matters",{{Cite journal|last=O'Dair|first=Sharon|year=2003|title=Class work: Site of egalitarian activism or site of embourgeoisement?|url=|journal=College English|volume=|pages=593–606|via=}} and further argues that this focus is at the expense of proficiency of student writing skills in the composition classroom. To this end, O'Dair explains that "recently advocated working-class pedagogies privilege activism over" language instruction." Jeff Smith argues that students want to gain, rather than to critique, positions of privilege, as encouraged by critical pedagogues.{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Smith|year=1997|title=Students' Goals, Gatekeeping, and Some Questions of Ethics|url=|journal=College English|volume=59|pages=299–320|via=}} There are a wide variety of views in opposition to critical pedagogy in the first year composition classroom, these are but a few. ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Adult education]] * [[Critical psychology]] * [[Critical thinking]] * [[Inclusive school]] * [[John Asimakopoulos]] * [[Praxis intervention]] * [[Praxis School]] * [[Rouge Forum]] * [[Social criticism]] * [[Student voice]] {{div col end}} == Further reading== Gottesman, Isaac (2016), ''The Critical Turn in Education: From Marxist Critique to Poststructuralist Feminism to Critical Theories of Race'' (New York: Routledge) == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Critical theory}} {{Freire}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Critical Pedagogy}} [[Category:Critical pedagogy| ]] [[Category:Philosophy of education]] [[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Critical theory]] [[Category:Popular education]] [[Category:Marxist theory]]

{{multiple issues|{{Medical citations needed|date=April 2012}} {{globalize|date=October 2017}}}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Developmental coordination disorder | synonyms = | field = [[Neurology]] & [[Psychiatry]] | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Developmental coordination disorder''' ('''DCD'''),<ref name="Polatajko Fox 1995">{{cite journal | vauthors = Polatajko H, Fox M, Missiuna C | title=An International Consensus on Children with Developmental Coordination Disorder|journal=Canadian Journal of Occupational Therapy|volume=62| issue=1|year=1995|pages=3–6 |doi=10.1177/000841749506200101}}</ref><ref name="Barnhart 2003">{{cite journal | vauthors = Barnhart RC, Davenport MJ, Epps SB, Nordquist VM | title = Developmental coordination disorder | journal = Physical Therapy | volume = 83 | issue = 8 | pages = 722–31 | date = August 2003 | pmid = 12882613 | url = http://ptjournal.apta.org/content/83/8/722.long }}</ref><ref name="Consensus Statements – CanChild">{{cite web |url=http://dcd.canchild.ca/en/dcdresources/consensusstatements.asp |title=Consensus Statements |format= |work=CanChild |access-date=}}</ref><ref name="Blank 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Blank R, Smits-Engelsman B, Polatajko H, Wilson P | title = European Academy for Childhood Disability (EACD): recommendations on the definition, diagnosis and intervention of developmental coordination disorder (long version) | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 54 | issue = 1 | pages = 54–93 | date = January 2012 | pmid = 22171930 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8749.2011.04171.x }}</ref><ref name="Zwicker 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Zwicker JG, Missiuna C, Harris SR, Boyd LA | title = Developmental coordination disorder: a review and update | journal = European Journal of Paediatric Neurology | volume = 16 | issue = 6 | pages = 573–81 | date = November 2012 | pmid = 22705270 | doi = 10.1016/j.ejpn.2012.05.005 }}</ref> also known as '''developmental dyspraxia''' or simply '''dyspraxia''',<ref name="Henderson 2003">{{cite journal | vauthors = Henderson SE, Henderson L | title = Toward an understanding of developmental coordination disorder: terminological and diagnostic issues | journal = Neural Plasticity | volume = 10 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 1–13 | year = 2003 | pmid = 14640303 | pmc = 2565424 | doi = 10.1155/NP.2003.1 }}</ref><ref name="Gibbs 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gibbs J, Appleton J, Appleton R | title = Dyspraxia or developmental coordination disorder? Unravelling the enigma | journal = Archives of Disease in Childhood | volume = 92 | issue = 6 | pages = 534–9 | date = June 2007 | pmid = 17515623 | pmc = 2066137 | doi = 10.1136/adc.2005.088054 }}</ref><ref name="Magalhães 2006">{{cite journal | vauthors = Magalhães LC, Missiuna C, Wong S | title = Terminology used in research reports of developmental coordination disorder | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 48 | issue = 11 | pages = 937–41 | date = November 2006 | pmid = 17044965 | doi = 10.1017/S0012162206002040 }}</ref><ref name="Kirby 2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kirby A, Edwards L, Sugden D, Rosenblum S | title = The development and standardization of the Adult Developmental Co-ordination Disorders/Dyspraxia Checklist (ADC) | journal = Research in Developmental Disabilities | volume = 31 | issue = 1 | pages = 131–9 | year = 2010 | pmid = 19819107 | doi = 10.1016/j.ridd.2009.08.010 }}</ref> is a chronic [[neurological disorder]] beginning in childhood. It is also known to affect [[Motor planning|planning of movements]] and co-ordination as a result of brain messages not being accurately transmitted to the body. Impairments in skilled motor movements per a child's chronological age interfere with activities of daily living.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|date=2013-05-22|publisher=American Psychiatric Association|isbn=978-0890425558|series=DSM Library | doi = 10.1176/appi.books.9780890425596.dsm01 |pmc=1408294|chapter=Neurodevelopmental Disorders}}</ref> A diagnosis of DCD is then reached only in the absence of other neurological impairments like [[cerebral palsy]],<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Pearsall-Jones JG, Piek JP, Levy F | title = Developmental Coordination Disorder and cerebral palsy: categories or a continuum? | journal = Human Movement Science | volume = 29 | issue = 5 | pages = 787–98 | date = October 2010 | pmid = 20594606 | doi = 10.1016/j.humov.2010.04.006 }}</ref> [[muscular dystrophy]],<ref name="Henderson 2003" /> [[multiple sclerosis]], or [[Parkinson's disease]]. According to CanChild in Canada, this disorder affects 5 to 6 percent of school-aged children;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canchild.ca/en/diagnoses/developmental-coordination-disorder|title=Developmental Coordination Disorder|work=CanChild (2016-02).}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} however, this disorder does progress towards adulthood, therefore making it a lifelong condition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.senteacher.org/specialistlinks/12/Dyspraxia.html|title=Dyspraxia Web Links|last=Evans|first=Simon|website=www.senteacher.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-31}}</ref>
== Classification == Developmental coordination disorder is classified in the fifth revision of the ''Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders'' ([[DSM-5]]) as a [[motor disorder]], in the category of [[neurodevelopmental disorder]]s.<ref name=DSM315.4>{{Cite book | author= American Psychiatric Association | year= 2013 | title=Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders | edition=Fifth | publisher=American Psychiatric Publishing | location=Arlington, VA | pages=74–7 | isbn= 978-0-89042-555-8 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Harris SR, Mickelson EC, Zwicker JG | title = Diagnosis and management of developmental coordination disorder | journal = Canadian Medical Association Journal | volume = 187 | issue = 9 | pages = 659–65 | date = June 2015 | pmid = 26009588 | pmc = 4467929 | doi = 10.1503/cmaj.140994 }}</ref>
== Signs and symptoms == Various areas of development can be affected by developmental coordination disorder and these will persist into adulthood,<ref name="Kirby 2010" /> as DCD has no cure. Often various coping strategies are developed, and these can be enhanced through occupational therapy, psychomotor therapy, physiotherapy, speech therapy, or psychological training.
In addition to the physical impairments, developmental coordination disorder is associated with problems with memory, especially [[working memory]].<ref name="Alloway Rajendran 2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Alloway TP, Rajendran G, Archibald LM | title = Working memory in children with developmental disorders | journal = Journal of Learning Disabilities | volume = 42 | issue = 4 | pages = 372–82 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19380495 | doi = 10.1177/0022219409335214 | hdl = 1893/863 }}</ref> This typically results in difficulty remembering instructions, difficulty organizing one's time and remembering deadlines, increased propensity to lose things or problems carrying out tasks which require remembering several steps in sequence (such as cooking). Whilst most of the general population experience these problems to some extent, they have a much more significant impact on the lives of dyspraxic people.<ref name="Biggs 2005 (3)">{{cite book | last1 = Biggs | first1 = Victoria | name-list-format = vanc | title = Caged in chaos : a dyspraxic guide to breaking free | chapter = 3 A Survival Guide to School | publisher = Jessica Kingsley Publishers | year = 2005 | location = London ; Philadelphia |oclc=57316751 | isbn = 978-1-84310-347-9 }}</ref> However, many dyspraxics have excellent [[Long-term memory|long-term memories]], despite poor [[short-term memory]].<ref name="Biggs 2005 (3)" /> Many dyspraxics benefit from working in a structured environment, as repeating the same routine minimises difficulty with time-management and allows them to commit procedures to long-term memory.
People with developmental coordination disorder sometimes have difficulty moderating the amount of sensory information that their body is constantly sending them, so as a result dyspraxics are prone to [[sensory overload]] and [[panic attack]]s.<ref name="Biggs 2005 (3)" />
Moderate to extreme difficulty doing physical tasks is experienced by some dyspraxics, and fatigue is common because so much energy is expended trying to execute physical movements correctly. Some dyspraxics suffer from [[hypotonia]], low muscle tone, which like DCD can detrimentally affect balance.<ref name="Barnhart 2003" />
=== Gross motor control === Whole body movement and [[motor coordination]] issues mean that major developmental targets including walking, running, climbing and jumping can be affected. The difficulties vary from person to person and can include the following: * Poor timing<ref name="Missiuna 2006">{{cite journal | vauthors = Missiuna C, Gaines R, Soucie H, McLean J | title = Parental questions about developmental coordination disorder: A synopsis of current evidence | journal = Paediatrics & Child Health | volume = 11 | issue = 8 | pages = 507–12 | date = October 2006 | pmid = 19030319 | pmc = 2528644 | doi = }}</ref> * Poor balance<ref name="Missiuna 2006" /><ref name="Geuze 2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Geuze RH | title = Postural control in children with developmental coordination disorder | journal = Neural Plasticity | volume = 12 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 183–96; discussion 263–72 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16097486 | pmc = 2565450 | doi = 10.1155/NP.2005.183 }}</ref> (sometimes even falling over in mid-step). Tripping over one's own feet is also common. * Difficulty combining movements into a controlled sequence. * Difficulty remembering the next movement in a sequence. * Problems with spatial awareness,<ref name="Geuze 2005" /><ref name="Wilson 1988">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wilson PH, McKenzie BE | title = Information processing deficits associated with developmental coordination disorder: a meta-analysis of research findings | journal = Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, and Allied Disciplines | volume = 39 | issue = 6 | pages = 829–40 | date = September 1998 | pmid = 9758192 | doi = 10.1111/1469-7610.00384 }}</ref> or [[proprioception]]. * Trouble picking up and holding onto simple objects such as pencils, owing to poor muscle tone or proprioception. * Clumsiness to the point of knocking things over, causing minor injuries to oneself and bumping into people accidentally. * Difficulty in [[Relative direction#Left-right confusion|determining left from right]]. * Cross-laterality, [[ambidexterity]], and a shift in the preferred hand are also common in people with developmental coordination disorder. * Problems with chewing foods.
=== Fine motor control === Fine-motor problems can cause difficulty with a wide variety of other tasks such as using a knife and fork, fastening buttons and shoelaces, cooking, brushing teeth, styling hair, shaving,<ref name="Barnhart 2003" /><ref name="Polatajko 2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Polatajko HJ, Cantin N | title = Developmental coordination disorder (dyspraxia): an overview of the state of the art | journal = Seminars in Pediatric Neurology | volume = 12 | issue = 4 | pages = 250–8 | date = December 2005 | pmid = 16780296 | doi = 10.1016/j.spen.2005.12.007 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1071909105000859 }}</ref> applying cosmetics, opening jars and packets, locking and unlocking doors, and doing housework.
Difficulties with fine motor co-ordination lead to problems with handwriting,<ref name="Barnhart 2003" /> which may be due to either ideational or ideo-motor difficulties.<ref name="Missiuna 2006" /><ref name="Rosenblum 2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rosenblum S | title = Handwriting measures as reflectors of executive functions among adults with Developmental Coordination Disorders (DCD) | journal = Frontiers in Psychology | volume = 4 | issue = | pages = 357 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23805113 | pmc = 3693067 | doi = 10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00357 }}</ref>{{primary source inline |date=October 2016}} Problems associated with this area may include: * Learning basic movement patterns.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lacquaniti F | title = Central representations of human limb movement as revealed by studies of drawing and handwriting | journal = Trends in Neurosciences | volume = 12 | issue = 8 | pages = 287–91 | date = August 1989 | pmid = 2475946 | doi = 10.1016/0166-2236(89)90008-8 }}</ref> * Developing a desired writing speed.<ref name="Polatajko 2005" /> * Establishing the correct pencil grip.<ref name="Polatajko 2005" /> * The acquisition of [[grapheme]]s – e.g. the letters of the [[Latin alphabet]], as well as numbers.<!-- this paragraph may not reliable as the reference is not a published journal , it is a blog and maybe the primary research -->
=== Developmental verbal dyspraxia === [[Developmental verbal dyspraxia|Developmental verbal dyspraxia (DVD)]] is a type of ideational dyspraxia, causing [[speech and language impairment]]s. This is the favoured term in the UK; however, it is also sometimes referred to as articulatory dyspraxia, and in the United States the usual term is childhood apraxia of speech (CAS).<ref name="Vargha-Khadem 2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Vargha-Khadem F, Gadian DG, Copp A, Mishkin M | title = FOXP2 and the neuroanatomy of speech and language | journal = Nature Reviews. Neuroscience | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | pages = 131–8 | date = February 2005 | pmid = 15685218 | doi = 10.1038/nrn1605 | url = http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic1169974.files/FOXP2%20review%20Vargha%20Khadem.pdf }}</ref><ref name="Bacon 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bacon C, Rappold GA | title = The distinct and overlapping phenotypic spectra of FOXP1 and FOXP2 in cognitive disorders | journal = Human Genetics | volume = 131 | issue = 11 | pages = 1687–98 | date = November 2012 | pmid = 22736078 | pmc = 3470686 | doi = 10.1007/s00439-012-1193-z }}</ref><ref name="Scharff 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Scharff C, Petri J | title = Evo-devo, deep homology and FoxP2: implications for the evolution of speech and language | journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences | volume = 366 | issue = 1574 | pages = 2124–40 | date = July 2011 | pmid = 21690130 | pmc = 3130369 | doi = 10.1098/rstb.2011.0001 }}</ref>
Key problems include: * Difficulties controlling the [[speech organ]]s. * Difficulties making speech sounds. * Difficulty sequencing sounds ** Within a word, and ** Forming words into sentences. * Difficulty controlling breathing, suppressing salivation and [[phonation]] when talking or singing with lyrics. * Slow [[language development]].<!-- this paragraph may not reliable as the reference is not a published journal , it is a blog and maybe the primary research -->
== Associated disorders and secondary consequences == People who have developmental coordination disorder may also have one or more of these co-morbid conditions: * [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder|Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)]] (inattention, hyperactivity, impulsive behaviour).<ref name="Kirby 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kirby A, Sugden DA | title = Children with developmental coordination disorders | journal = Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine | volume = 100 | issue = 4 | pages = 182–6 | date = April 2007 | pmid = 17404341 | pmc = 1847727 | doi = 10.1258/jrsm.100.4.182 }}</ref><ref name="Fliers 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Fliers EA, Franke B, Buitelaar JK | title = [Motor problems in children with ADHD receive too little attention in clinical practice] | language = Dutch | journal = Nederlands Tijdschrift voor Geneeskunde | volume = 155 | issue = 50 | pages = A3559 | year = 2011 | pmid = 22186361 }}</ref><ref name="Gillberg 2003">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gillberg C, Kadesjö B | title = Why bother about clumsiness? The implications of having developmental coordination disorder (DCD) | journal = Neural Plasticity | volume = 10 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 59–68 | year = 2003 | pmid = 14640308 | pmc = 2565425 | doi = 10.1155/NP.2003.59 }}</ref> * [[Autism spectrum disorder]].<ref name="Gillberg 2003" /><ref name="Dziuk 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dziuk MA, Gidley Larson JC, Apostu A, Mahone EM, Denckla MB, Mostofsky SH | title = Dyspraxia in autism: association with motor, social, and communicative deficits | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 49 | issue = 10 | pages = 734–9 | date = October 2007 | pmid = 17880641 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8749.2007.00734.x }}</ref><ref name="Jeste 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Jeste SS | title = The neurology of autism spectrum disorders | journal = Current Opinion in Neurology | volume = 24 | issue = 2 | pages = 132–9 | date = April 2011 | pmid = 21293268 | pmc = 3160764 | doi = 10.1097/WCO.0b013e3283446450 }}</ref><ref name="Miyahara 2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Miyahara M | title = Meta review of systematic and meta analytic reviews on movement differences, effect of movement based interventions, and the underlying neural mechanisms in autism spectrum disorder | journal = Frontiers in Integrative Neuroscience | volume = 7 | pages = 16 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23532374 | pmc = 3607787 | doi = 10.3389/fnint.2013.00016 }}</ref> * [[Dyscalculia]] (difficulty with numbers).<ref name="Pieters 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Pieters S, Desoete A, Van Waelvelde H, Vanderswalmen R, Roeyers H | title = Mathematical problems in children with developmental coordination disorder | journal = Research in Developmental Disabilities | volume = 33 | issue = 4 | pages = 1128–35 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22502838 | doi = 10.1016/j.ridd.2012.02.007 }}</ref> * [[Dysgraphia]] (an inability to write neatly or draw).<ref name="Van Waelvelde 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Van Waelvelde H, Hellinckx T, Peersman W, Smits-Engelsman BC | title = SOS: a screening instrument to identify children with handwriting impairments | journal = Physical & Occupational Therapy in Pediatrics | volume = 32 | issue = 3 | pages = 306–19 | date = August 2012 | pmid = 22515913 | doi = 10.3109/01942638.2012.678971 | hdl = 1854/LU-2103056 }}</ref>. * [[Dyslexia]] (difficulty with reading and spelling).<ref name=Pickering2012>{{cite book | first = Susan J. | last = Pickering | name-list-format = vanc | chapter = Chapter 2: Working Memory in Dyslexia | editor-first1=Tracy | editor-last1 = Packiam Alloway | editor-first2 = Susan E. | editor-last2 = Gathercole | title = Working Memory and Neurodevelopmental Disorders|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoXidOBdNpMC&pg=PA29|year=2012|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-135-42134-2}}</ref>{{rp|28}} * [[Hypotonia]] (low muscle tone).<ref name="Barnhart 2003" /> * [[Sensory processing disorder]].<ref name="Elbasan 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Elbasan B, Kayıhan H, Duzgun I | title = Sensory integration and activities of daily living in children with developmental coordination disorder | journal = Italian Journal of Pediatrics | volume = 38 | issue = 1 | pages = 14 | date = April 2012 | pmid = 22546072 | pmc = 3395584 | doi = 10.1186/1824-7288-38-14 }}</ref><ref name="Biggs 2005 (2)">{{cite book | last1 = Biggs | first1 = Victoria | name-list-format = vanc | title = Caged in chaos : a dyspraxic guide to breaking free | chapter = 2 The Hidden People at Home | publisher = Jessica Kingsley Publishers | year = 2005 | location = London; Philadelphia | isbn = 978-1-84310-347-9 |oclc = 57316751}}</ref> * [[Specific language impairment|Specific language impairment (SLI)]].<ref name="Alloway 2008">{{cite journal | vauthors = Alloway TP, Archibald L | title = Working memory and learning in children with developmental coordination disorder and specific language impairment | journal = Journal of Learning Disabilities | volume = 41 | issue = 3 | pages = 251–62 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18434291 | doi = 10.1177/0022219408315815 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.541.7017 }}</ref> * [[Visual perception]] deficits.<ref name="Schoemaker 2001">{{cite journal | vauthors = Schoemaker MM, van der Wees M, Flapper B, Verheij-Jansen N, Scholten-Jaegers S, Geuze RH | title = Perceptual skills of children with developmental coordination disorder | journal = Human Movement Science | volume = 20 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 111–33 | date = March 2001 | pmid = 11471393 | doi = 10.1016/s0167-9457(01)00031-8 | url = http://share.eldoc.ub.rug.nl/FILES/root2/2001/Percskofc/Schoenmakers_2001_Human_Movement_Science.pdf }}</ref>
However, they are unlikely to have all of these conditions. The pattern of difficulty varies widely from person to person; an area of major weakness for one dyspraxic can be an area of strength or gift for another. For example, while some dyspraxics have difficulty with reading and spelling due to dyslexia, or with numeracy due to dyscalculia, others may have brilliant reading and spelling or mathematical abilities. Some estimates show that up to 50% of dyspraxics have ADHD.<ref name="Barkley 1990">{{cite book | last = Barkley | first = Russell A. | name-list-format = vanc |title=Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder: a handbook for diagnosis and treatment |publisher=Guilford Press |location=New York |year=1990 |pages= |isbn=978-0-89862-443-4 |oclc=21335369 |access-date=}}</ref><!-- v --><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cravedi E, Deniau E, Giannitelli M, Xavier J, Hartmann A, Cohen D | title = Tourette syndrome and other neurodevelopmental disorders: a comprehensive review | journal = Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and Mental Health | volume = 11 | pages = 59 | date = 2017-12-04 | pmid = 29225671 | pmc = 5715991 | doi = 10.1186/s13034-017-0196-x }}</ref>
=== Sensory processing disorder === {{Main|Sensory processing disorder}} '''Sensory Processing Disorder (SPD)''' concerns having oversensitivity or undersensitivity to physical stimuli, such as touch, light, sound, and smell.<ref name="Miller 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Miller LJ, Anzalone ME, Lane SJ, Cermak SA, Osten ET | title = Concept evolution in sensory integration: a proposed nosology for diagnosis | journal = The American Journal of Occupational Therapy | volume = 61 | issue = 2 | pages = 135–40 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17436834 | doi = 10.5014/ajot.61.2.135 | url = http://www.spdfoundation.net/pdf/Miller_Anzalone.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121024223226/http://spdfoundation.net/pdf/Miller_Anzalone.pdf | df = | deadurl = yes | archive-date = 2012-10-24 }}</ref> This may manifest itself as an inability to tolerate certain textures such as [[sandpaper]] or certain fabrics such as wool, oral intolerance of excessively textured food (commonly known as picky eating), being touched by another individual (in the case of touch oversensitivity) or it may require the consistent use of sunglasses outdoors since sunlight may be intense enough to cause discomfort to a dyspraxic (in the case of light oversensitivity). An aversion to loud music and naturally loud environments (such as clubs and bars) is typical behavior of a dyspraxic individual who suffers from [[Hyperacusis|auditory oversensitivity]], while only being comfortable in unusually warm or cold environments is typical of a dyspraxic with temperature oversensitivity. Undersensitivity to stimuli may also cause problems. Dyspraxics who are undersensitive to pain may injure themselves without realising it.<ref name="Biggs 2005 (2)" /> Some dyspraxics may be oversensitive to some stimuli and undersensitive to others.<ref name="Biggs 2005 (2)" />
=== Specific language impairment === {{Main|Specific language impairment}} '''Specific Language Impairment (SLI)''' research has found that students with developmental coordination disorder and normal language skills still experience learning difficulties despite relative strengths in language. This means that for students with developmental coordination disorder their working memory abilities determine their learning difficulties. Any strength in language that they have is not able to sufficiently support their learning.<ref name="Alloway 2008" />
Students with developmental coordination disorder struggle most in visual-spatial memory. When compared to their peers who don’t have motor difficulties, students with developmental coordination disorder are seven times more likely than typically developing students to achieve very poor scores in visual-spatial memory.<ref name="Alloway 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Alloway TP | title = Working memory, reading, and mathematical skills in children with developmental coordination disorder | journal = Journal of Experimental Child Psychology | volume = 96 | issue = 1 | pages = 20–36 | date = January 2007 | pmid = 17010988 | doi = 10.1016/j.jecp.2006.07.002 | hdl = 1893/800 }}</ref> As a result of this working memory impairment, students with developmental coordination disorder have learning deficits as well.<ref name="Alloway Temple 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Alloway TP, Temple K | title=A Comparison of Working Memory Profiles and Learning in Children with Developmental Coordination Disorder and Moderate Learning Difficulties|journal=Applied Cognitive Psychology| volume=21| issue=4| pages=473–487| year=2007 |doi=10.1002/acp.1284}}</ref>
=== Psychological and social consequences === '''Psychological domain:''' Children with DCD struggle with lower self-efficacy and lower self-perceived competence in peer and social relations. They demonstrate greater aggressiveness and hyperactivity.<ref name="Zwicker 562–580">{{cite journal | vauthors = Zwicker JG, Harris SR, Klassen AF | title = Quality of life domains affected in children with developmental coordination disorder: a systematic review | journal = Child | volume = 39 | issue = 4 | pages = 562–80 | date = July 2013 | pmid = 22515477 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2214.2012.01379.x }}</ref>
'''Social domain:''' Children are more vulnerable to social rejection and bullying, along with higher levels of loneliness.<ref name="Zwicker 562–580" />
== Diagnosis == Assessments for developmental coordination disorder typically require a developmental history,<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /> detailing ages at which significant [[developmental milestones]], such as [[crawling (human)|crawling]] and [[walking]],<ref name="Zwicker 2012" /><ref name="Henderson 2003" /><ref name="Kirby 2007" /> occurred. Motor skills screening includes activities designed to indicate developmental coordination disorder, including balancing, physical sequencing, touch sensitivity, and variations on walking activities.
The [[American Psychiatric Association]] has four primary inclusive diagnostic criteria{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kirby A, Sugden DA | title = Children with developmental coordination disorders | journal = Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine | volume = 100 | issue = 4 | pages = 182–6 | date = April 2007 | pmid = 17404341 | pmc = 1847727 | doi = 10.1177/014107680710011414 }}</ref> for determining if a [[child]] has developmental coordination disorder.
The criteria are as follows: # Motor Coordination will be greatly reduced, although the intelligence of the child is normal for the age. # The difficulties the child experiences with motor coordination or planning interfere with the child's daily life. # The difficulties with coordination are not due to any other medical condition # If the child does also experience comorbidities such as mental retardation; motor coordination is still disproportionally affected.<ref name="Gibbs 2007"/>
Screening tests that can be used to assess developmental coordination disorder include: * Movement Assessment Battery for Children ([[Movement-ABC]] – [[Movement-ABC 2]])<ref name="Cools-2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Cools W, Martelaer KD, Samaey C, Andries C | title = Movement skill assessment of typically developing preschool children: a review of seven movement skill assessment tools | journal = Journal of Sports Science & Medicine | volume = 8 | issue = 2 | pages = 154–68 | date = June 2009 | pmid = 24149522 | pmc = 3761481 | doi = }}</ref><ref name="Wright-1996">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wright HC, Sugden DA | title = A two-step procedure for the identification of children with developmental co-ordination disorder in Singapore | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 38 | issue = 12 | pages = 1099–105 | date = December 1996 | pmid = 8973295 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8749.1996.tb15073.x }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}}<ref name="Venetsanou 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Venetsanou F, Kambas A, Ellinoudis T, Fatouros I, Giannakidou D, Kourtessis T | title = Can the movement assessment battery for children-test be the "gold standard" for the motor assessment of children with Developmental Coordination Disorder? | journal = Research in Developmental Disabilities | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–10 | year = 2011 | pmid = 20940096 | doi = 10.1016/j.ridd.2010.09.006 }}</ref><ref name="Ellinoudis 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ellinoudis T, Evaggelinou C, Kourtessis T, Konstantinidou Z, Venetsanou F, Kambas A | title = Reliability and validity of age band 1 of the Movement Assessment Battery for Children--second edition | journal = Research in Developmental Disabilities | volume = 32 | issue = 3 | pages = 1046–51 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21333488 | doi = 10.1016/j.ridd.2011.01.035 }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}}<ref name="Schoemaker Niemeijer 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Schoemaker MM, Niemeijer AS, Flapper BC, Smits-Engelsman BC | title = Validity and reliability of the Movement Assessment Battery for Children-2 Checklist for children with and without motor impairments | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 54 | issue = 4 | pages = 368–75 | date = April 2012 | pmid = 22320829 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8749.2012.04226.x }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}} * Peabody Developmental Motor Scales- Second Edition (PDMS-2)<ref name="Cools-2009" /> * Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency (BOTMP-BOT-2)<ref name="Cools-2009" /><ref name="Venetsanou 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Venetsanou F, Kambas A, Aggeloussis N, Serbezis V, Taxildaris K | title = Use of the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency for identifying children with motor impairment | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 49 | issue = 11 | pages = 846–8 | date = November 2007 | pmid = 17979863 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8749.2007.00846.x }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}}<ref name="Venetsanou 2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Venetsanou F, Kambas A, Aggeloussis N, Fatouros I, Taxildaris K | title = Motor assessment of preschool aged children: A preliminary investigation of the validity of the Bruininks-Oseretsky test of motor proficiency - short form | journal = Human Movement Science | volume = 28 | issue = 4 | pages = 543–50 | date = August 2009 | pmid = 19443065 | doi = 10.1016/j.humov.2009.03.002 | url = https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00557316 }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}}<ref name="Lucas 2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lucas BR, Latimer J, Doney R, Ferreira ML, Adams R, Hawkes G, Fitzpatrick JP, Hand M, Oscar J, Carter M, Elliott EJ | title = The Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-Short Form is reliable in children living in remote Australian Aboriginal communities | journal = BMC Pediatrics | volume = 13 | issue = | pages = 135 | date = September 2013 | pmid = 24010634 | pmc = 3844452 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2431-13-135 }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}} * Motoriktest für vier- bis sechsjährige Kinder (MOT 4-6)<ref name="Cools-2009" /><ref name="Kambas 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kambas A, Venetsanou F, Giannakidou D, Fatouros IG, Avloniti A, Chatzinikolaou A, Draganidis D, Zimmer R | title = The Motor-Proficiency-Test for children between 4 and 6 years of age (MOT 4-6): an investigation of its suitability in Greece | journal = Research in Developmental Disabilities | volume = 33 | issue = 5 | pages = 1626–32 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22543059 | doi = 10.1016/j.ridd.2012.04.002 }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}} * Körperkoordinationtest für Kinder ([[Körperkoordinationtest für Kinder|KTK]])<ref name="Cools-2009" /> * Test of Gross Motor Development, Second Edition ([[TGMD-2]])<ref name="Cools-2009" /> * Maastrichtse Motoriek Test ([[Maastrichtse Motoriek Test|MMT]])<ref name="Cools-2009" /> * Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale ([[WAIS-IV]]){{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * Wechsler Individual Achievement Test ([[WAIT-II]]){{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * Test of Word Reading Efficiency ([[TOWRE-2]]){{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * Developmental Coordination Disorder Questionnaire ([[Developmental coordination disorder - questionnaire|DCD-Q]])<ref name = "Schoemaker_20006">{{cite journal | vauthors = Schoemaker MM, Flapper B, Verheij NP, Wilson BN, Reinders-Messelink HA, de Kloet A | title = Evaluation of the Developmental Coordination Disorder Questionnaire as a screening instrument | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 48 | issue = 8 | pages = 668–73 | date = August 2006 | pmid = 16836779 | doi = 10.1017/S001216220600140X }}</ref> * Children's Self-Perceptions of Adequacy in, and Predilection for Physical Activity ([[Children's Self-Perceptions of Adequacy in, and Predilection for Physical Activity|CSAPPA]])<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hay JA, Hawes R, Faught BE | title = Evaluation of a screening instrument for developmental coordination disorder | journal = The Journal of Adolescent Health | volume = 34 | issue = 4 | pages = 308–13 | date = April 2004 | pmid = 15041000 | doi = 10.1016/j.jadohealth.2003.07.004 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/S1054-139X(03)00268-4 }}</ref> Currently there is no single gold standard assessment test.<ref name="Cools-2009" />
A baseline motor assessment establishes the starting point for developmental intervention programs. Comparing children to normal rates of development may help to establish areas of significant difficulty.
However, research in the ''[[British Journal of Special Education]]'' has shown that knowledge is severely limited in many who should be trained to recognise and respond to various difficulties, including developmental coordination disorder, [[dyslexia]] and [[Deficits in Attention, Motor control and Perception|deficits in attention, motor control and perception (DAMP)]].<ref name="Kirby 2007" /> The earlier that difficulties are noted and timely assessments occur, the quicker intervention can begin. A teacher or [[General practitioner|GP]] could miss a diagnosis if they are only applying a cursory knowledge.
<blockquote>"Teachers will not be able to recognise or accommodate the child with learning difficulties in class if their knowledge is limited. Similarly GPs will find it difficult to detect and appropriately refer children with learning difficulties."<ref name="Kirby Davies 2005">{{cite journal|last1=Kirby| first1=Amanda|last2=Davies|first2=Rhys|last3=Bryant| first3=Amy | name-list-format = vanc |title=Do teachers know more about specific learning difficulties than general practitioners?|journal=British Journal of Special Education| volume=32|issue=3| year=2005|pages=122–126|issn=0952-3383|doi=10.1111/j.0952-3383.2005.00384.x}}</ref>{{primary source inline |date=October 2016}}</blockquote>
==Management== There is no cure for the condition. Instead, it is managed through therapy. [[Occupational therapy]] or [[cognitive behavioral therapy]] can help those living with the condition.
Some people with the condition find it helpful to find alternative ways of carrying out tasks or organizing themselves, such as typing on a laptop instead of writing by hand, or using diaries and calendars to keep organized.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/developmental-coordination-disorder-dyspraxia-in-adults/#treatment-for-dyspraxia | title=Dyspraxia (developmental co-ordination disorder) in adults| date=2017-10-18}}</ref>
== Epidemiology == Developmental coordination disorder is a lifelong [[neurological]] condition that is more common in [[males]] than in [[females]], with a ratio of approximately four males to every female. The exact proportion of people with the disorder is unknown since the disorder can be difficult to detect due to a lack of specific laboratory tests, thus making diagnosis of the condition one of elimination of all other possible causes/diseases. Approximately 5–6% of [[children]] are affected by this condition.<ref name="Barnhart 2003" /><ref name="Blank 2012" /><ref name="Zwicker 2012" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gaines R, Missiuna C, Egan M, McLean J | title = Educational outreach and collaborative care enhances physician's perceived knowledge about Developmental Coordination Disorder | journal = BMC Health Services Research | volume = 8 | pages = 21 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18218082 | pmc = 2254381 | doi = 10.1186/1472-6963-8-21 | url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6963/8/21 }}</ref>{{Primary source inline |date=October 2016}}<!---What about adults??? Amanda Kirby and others clearly stated in the references adults are affected too.--->
== History == Collier first described developmental coordination disorder as 'congenital maladroitness'. [[Anna Jean Ayres|A. Jean Ayres]] referred to developmental coordination disorder as a disorder of sensory integration in 1972,<ref name="Ayres 1972">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ayres AJ | title = Types of sensory integrative dysfunction among disabled learners | journal = The American Journal of Occupational Therapy | volume = 26 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–8 | year = 1972 | pmid = 5008164 | doi = }}</ref><ref name="Willoughby 1995">{{cite journal | vauthors = Willoughby C, Polatajko HJ | title = Motor problems in children with developmental coordination disorder: review of the literature | journal = The American Journal of Occupational Therapy | volume = 49 | issue = 8 | pages = 787–94 | date = September 1995 | pmid = 8526224 | doi = 10.5014/ajot.49.8.787 | url = http://ajot.aotapress.net/content/49/8/787.full.pdf+html }}</ref> while in 1975 Sasson Gubbay, MD, called it the 'clumsy child syndrome'.<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /><ref name="Gillberg 2003" /><ref name="Gubbay 1978">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gubbay SS | title = The management of developmental apraxia | journal = Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology | volume = 20 | issue = 5 | pages = 643–6 | date = October 1978 | pmid = 729912 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8749.1978.tb15283.x }}</ref> Developmental coordination disorder has also been called minimal brain dysfunction although the two latter names are no longer in use.
Other names include: Developmental Apraxia,<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /> [[Deficits in attention, motor control and perception|Disorder of Attention and Motor Perception (DAMP)]]<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /><ref name="Gillberg 2003" /> Dyspraxia,<ref name="Henderson 2003" /> Developmental Dyspraxia,<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /> Motor Learning Difficulties,<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /><ref name="Gillberg 2003" /> Perceptuo-motor dysfunction,<ref name="Gibbs 2007" /><ref name="Gillberg 2003" /><ref name="Willoughby 1995" /> Sensorimotor dysfunction.<ref name="Gibbs 2007" />
The World Health Organisation currently lists developmental coordination disorder as Specific Developmental Disorder of Motor Function.<ref name="Henderson 2003" />
== Notable cases == People who have publicly stated they have been diagnosed with developmental coordination disorder include actor [[Daniel Radcliffe]],<ref name="Irvine 2008">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/2573230/Harry-Potters-Daniel-Radcliffe-has-dyspraxia.html |title=Harry Potter's Daniel Radcliffe has dyspraxia |access-date=2010-05-16 |work= The Daily Telegraph|location=London |first=Chris |last=Irvine | name-list-format = vanc |date=2008-08-17}}</ref> photographer [[David Bailey (photographer)|David Bailey]],<ref>{{cite news |last1=Walsh |first1=John |title=David Bailey was a scowling, socially mobile rude boy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/david-bailey-introduced-us-to-the-concept-of-the-portrait-photographer-as-style-arbiter-and-sex-god-a6788881.html |work=The Independent |date=2 January 2016}}</ref> model [[Cara Delevingne]],<ref name="vogue">{{cite web |last=Haskell |first=Rob | name-list-format = vanc |url=http://www.vogue.com/13268025/cara-delevingne-actress-july-2015-cover/ |title=Cara Delevingne Opens Up About Her Childhood, Love Life, and Why Modeling Just Isn't Enough |publisher=Vogue |date=19 June 2015 |access-date=14 September 2015}}</ref> singer [[Florence Welch]],<ref name="runriot">{{cite web |last=Hussey |first=Patrick | name-list-format = vanc |url=http://www.run-riot.com/articles/blogs/interview-florence-machine |title=Interview: Florence & The Machine |publisher=Run Riot |date=15 May 2008 |access-date=7 March 2010}}</ref> UK politician [[Emma Lewell-Buck]],<ref name="Irvine 2013">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-life/10341479/Id-love-to-wear-eyeliner-but-that-requires-a-steady-hand.html |title='I’d love to wear eyeliner, but that requires a steady hand’ Labour MP Emma Lewell-Buck struggled with clumsiness, until a diagnosis of dyspraxia helped her become a politician |access-date=2013-09-28 |work= The Daily Telegraph|location=London |first=Chris |last=Irvine | name-list-format = vanc |date=2013-09-28}}</ref> comedian Harriet Kemsley,<ref>http://www.dyspraxialifemagazine.co.uk/2018/10/01/standing-up-for-dyspraxia/</ref> rugby player Ellis Genge,<ref>http://rugbylad.ie/ellis-genge-talk-tv-last-night-incredible-interview/</ref> and footballer Stephen Lewis <ref>http://www.dyspraxialifemagazine.co.uk/2018/10/02/dyspraxic-footballer/</ref>
==Fictional representations== Ryan Sinclair, a human companion of [[the Doctor (Doctor Who)|the Doctor]] in the [[BBC]] [[Science fiction on television|science fiction television]] programme ''[[Doctor Who]]'' has the disorder. The character debuted in 2018.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gerken |first1=Tom |title=Doctor Who: How the dyspraxic assistant became my hero |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-45784822 |website=BBC News |publisher=BBC |accessdate=16 October 2018|date=2018-10-08 }}</ref>
