revision.text:
{{Use British English | date = February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}}
{{Infobox person | name = Robert Jackson | image = Researcher Robert Jackson (cropped).jpg | caption = Jackson in 2017 | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1945}} | birth_place = {{flag|United Kingdom}} | occupation = professor, educator and educational researcher | awards = William Rainey Harper Award; Honorary doctorate at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU); Honorary doctorate at the Norwegian School of Theology (MF) | nationality = [[British people|British]] | |}} '''Robert Mason David "Bob"<ref>[https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/ces/research/wreru/aboutus/staff/rj/jazz/ Nickname used both in the "jazz world" and among colleagues. See also his WRERU profile]</ref> Jackson''' (born 11 June 1945) is a British [[teacher|educator]] and [[educational research]]er working in the fields of [[Religious education in primary and secondary education|religious]] and [[Intercultural competence|intercultural education]] in [[United Kingdom|the UK]] and internationally, and in [[Education|educational policy]] at the European level. He has authored several influential books on an inclusive form of religious education in which young people learn together about religious and world view diversity, and has contributed to policy development on the religious dimension of intercultural education for the [[Council of Europe]]. He has written and presented educational broadcasts for [[BBC Schools|BBC Education]], and has edited both professional and academic journals. His work has been influential in a variety of countries beyond Europe. Away from academic work, he is a jazz musician and poet.
==Education and teaching== He was born in [[Ilkeston]], [[Derbyshire]] in 1945. He attended [[Hallcroft school]], then studied [[Theology]] at [[University of Wales, Lampeter|St David’s College, Lampeter]] (1963–1966), and for a [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education]] (PGCE) at the [[University of Cambridge]] (1966–67), where he was a member of [[Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge|Fitzwilliam College]], and a member of the [[Footlights|Footlights Dramatic Club]]. He completed an MA degree in Philosophy in 1975, and [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in Arts Education in 1994 at the University of Warwick.
He taught at [[Nottingham High School]] 1967–1971, and at [[Coventry College of Education]] 1972–78, joining the Department of Arts Education (later Institute of Education, and then the Centre for Education Studies) at the [[University of Warwick]] in April 1978, becoming Professor of Religions and Education in 1995. He held Visiting Fellowships in Religions and Education at the [[SOAS, University of London|School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London]], in Autumn 1974 and Spring 1978, the first leading to the publication of ''Perspectives on World Religions'',<ref>Jackson, R. (Ed.) (1978) ''Perspectives on World Religions''. London : University of London School of Oriental and African Studies. {{ISBN|0728600552}}</ref> and the second to a series of BBC Education broadcasts on [[Rite of passage|rites of passage]] experienced by members of religious communities in Britain.<ref>Blaylock, L., Jackson, R. and Marshall-Taylor, G. «Image and Imagination: Religious Education at the BBC». In: ''RE Today'', 19 (3), 28–9. ISSN 0226 7738</ref>
He was awarded a [[Doctor of Letters|DLitt degree]] by the University of Wales, Lampeter in 2006 for a selection of his published work.<ref>[https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/ces/research/wreru/aboutus/staff/rj/ WRERU on professor Robert Jackson]</ref>
==Empirical research== Influenced by meeting families of South Asian background in Coventry from 1972, Jackson began ethnographic research on [[Hindu]] families in Britain. He was joined in this work by Eleanor Nesbitt, and a report of their research was published in 1993.<ref>Jackson, R. and Nesbitt, E. (1993) ''Hindu Children in Britain''. Stoke on Trent: Trentham. {{ISBN|0948080736}}</ref> Following the formation of the Institute of Education<ref>[https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/ces/ The Institute's website]</ref> at the University of Warwick in 1994, Jackson established and became Director of the Warwick Religions and Education Research Unit (WRERU) until his retirement from full-time work in 2012. He remains an active member of WRERU. Jackson led WRERU’s contribution to the REDCo (Religion, Education, Dialogue, Conflict) Project, a European research project on religious education involving researchers, teachers and students from eight countries, funded by the European Commission.<ref>[http://www.shapworkingparty.org.uk/downloads/Redco.pdf About REDCo]</ref> WRERU has continued with a range of externally funded studies with funding from sources including the UK Research Councils and charitable bodies.
Jackson was invited to become a member of the Steering Committee of ‘Religion and Society’ (2007–2012),<ref>[http://www.religionandsociety.org.uk/about/programme_management/steering_committee The Steering Committe's website]</ref> an extensive UK research programme, taking a particular interest in projects concerned with education and youth, leading to the publication of a special issue of ''the Journal of Beliefs and Values'' in 2012, and a book co-edited with Elisabeth Arweck.<ref>Arweck, E. and Jackson, R. (eds.)(2014) ''Religion, Education and Society : Young People, Religious Identity, Socialisation and Diversity.'' London: Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415824729}}</ref>
Jackson’s ideas have been developed in various research contexts by others, including quantitative and qualitative studies, as well as action research studies undertaken by practitioners.<ref>Miller, J., O'GRady, K. and McKenna, U. (eds.) (2013) ''Religion in Education : Innovation i International Research''. New York and London: Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415659499}}</ref><ref>[http://www.theewc.org/news/view/publications.in.honour.of.robert.jackson.university.of.warwick.and.european.wergeland.centre/ The Wergeland Centre on publications in honour of Robert Jackson]</ref> Jackson’s ideas have also been discussed with a view to adapting them to other national contexts, such as the USA.<ref>Grelle, Bruce (2006) «Defining and Promoting the Study of Religion in British and American Schools». In: M. de Souza, K. Engebretson, G. Durka, R. Jackson and A. McGrady (eds.), ''International Handbook of the Religious, Moral and Spiritual Dimensions of Education'', pp 461-474. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Springer Academic Publishers. {{ISBN|9781402048036}}</ref>
==Religious education theory and didactics== [[File:Robert Jackson British educator.jpg|thumb|260px|Jackson receiving his honorary doctorate diploma at NTNU, Trondheim in 2017. Left: NTNU's rector [[Gunnar Bovim]]]] Jackson has continued to argue that an open and inclusive study of religions and other worldviews in state funded schools is intrinsic to a broadly based liberal education, while also contributing instrumentally to the personal development of students and to social aims, such as fostering appreciation for the human rights principle freedom of religion and belief.<ref>[http://cadmus.eui.eu/handle/1814/37735 Jackson, R. (2015) «Inclusive Study of Religions and Other Worldviews in Publicly-funded Schools in Democratic Societies». in Kristina Stoeckl and Olivier Roy (eds.) ''The Future of Religious Education in Europe'', pp 7–18. San Domenico di Fiesole: European University Institute. (Open access e-book)]</ref>
Drawing on ideas and methods from his ethnographic studies, Jackson developed the interpretive approach to religious education, which examines the dynamic relationship between individuals, the various kinds of groups they relate to, and wider religious traditions.<ref>Jackson, R. (1997) ''Religious Education: An Interpretive Approach''. London: Hodder and Stoughton. {{ISBN|978-0340688700}}</ref> It was influenced by work in recent [[social anthropology]], [[hermeneutics]], [[religious studies]], [[Intercultural relations|intercultural studies]] and [[social psychology]], and deals with issues of representing and interpreting religions fairly and accurately. It also includes a reflexive dimension in which the learner or researcher reflects on the implications of new learning for their own personal development. Professor [[John M. Hull]] described ''Religious Education: An Interpretive Approach'' as «a major contribution to the academic and professional study of religious education.»<ref>«''Religious Education: An Interpretive Approach'', Robert Jackson, Hodder & Stoughton, 1997, 0–340–68870–X. Reviewed by John M Hull, Professor of Religious Education in the University of Birmingham». In ''British Journal of Religious Education'' (1998) 20 (2), pp 125–128</ref>
In his work on religious education and plurality,<ref>Jackson, R. (2004) ''Rethinking Religious Education and Plurality: Issues in Diversity and Pedagogy''. London: Routledge. {{ISBN|978-0415302722}}</ref> Jackson argues that the educational potential of the study of religion in state-funded schools has been underestimated; state schools should not be thought of as places of secular education, but as providing a pluralist context for educational development, and an environment encouraging dialogue. In reviewing ''Rethinking Religious Education and Plurality'', John M. Hull wrote: «Jackson’s masterly work not only helps us to rethink religious education; it shows its wider educational significance and points to its exciting future».<ref>Book Review by John Hull, ''British Educational Research Journal'' 32, (1), February 2006, pp. 151–152.</ref>
Jackson’s latest book – ''Religious Education for Plural Societies'' – is a compilation of selected writings from across his career organised into sections on empirical research; the interpretive approach to religious education; religious education and plurality; and human rights and international policy development. A substantial general introduction is provided, plus introductions for each section.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Religious-Education-Plural-Societies-Educationalis/dp/1138550671/|title=Religious Education for Plural Societies: The Selected Works of Robert Jackson|last=Jackson|first=Robert|date=|publisher=Routledge|year=2018|isbn=9781138550674|edition= 1st|location=|pages=|language=English}}</ref>
==Broadcasting== Jackson’s work on families of religious minorities attracted the attention of BBC Education producers Ralph Rolls and Geoffrey Marshall-Taylor, and they invited him to make radio and radiovision programmes for school students of various ages, using actuality material and interviews.<ref>Marshall-Taylor, G. (2010) «Strawberry Fields ... For Ever? Personal recollections on the BBC’s support for RE and collective worship». In: ''REsource'', 33:1, pp. 10-12.</ref>
==Editorships== Jackson edited ''Resource'', which became the journal of the National Association for Teachers of Religious Education, from 1978 to 1996.<ref>Albans, P. (1996) ''Resource'', 19, 1, p. 3</ref> In 1996, he succeeded John Hull as Editor of the ''British Journal of Religious Education'', which he continued to do until 2011.<ref>Jackson, R (2011) «Religion, education, dialogue and conflict: editorial introduction», ''British Journal of Religious Education'', 33: 2, 105-109.</ref> Jackson extended Hull’s policy of enhancing the academic status of the journal, including increasing its international profile, setting up editorial and international advisory boards, taking the journal to a commercial publisher, and gaining its inclusion in the [[Thomson Reuters Indices|Thomson Reuter citation index]].<ref>«Editorial (2008): The evolution of the British Journal of Religious Education: 30th and 74th birthdays», ''British Journal of Religious Education'', 30, (3), September 2008, pp. 183–186</ref>
Jackson serves on the editorial boards of a range of European and international journals. He is co-editor of ‘Religious Diversity and Education in Europe’ an extensive book series published in Germany by Waxmann,<ref>[http://www.waxmann.com/reihe1862-9547 Waxmann on the series]</ref> and is a contributing editor to the University of Vienna’s book series on Religious Education at Schools in Europe,<ref>[http://www.rel-edu.eu/authors/ University of Vienna on the series]</ref> and to Springer’s ''International Handbooks on Religion and Education''.<ref>[https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/1-4020-5246-4 Springer on the handbook series]</ref>
==Policy development== Jackson has been involved with the [[Council of Europe]]’s work on policy for religion and education since it first included this topic in 2002. He participated in a project on the Religious dimension of intercultural education which produced publications in 2004<ref>Council of Europe (2004) ''The Religious Dimension of Intercultural Education''. Strasbourg: Council of Europe Publishing</ref> and 2007.<ref>Keast, J. (ed.) (2007) ''Religious Diversity and Intercultural Education: A Reference Book for Schools''. Strasbourg: Council of Europe Publishing</ref> He co-organised the first Council of Europe «Exchange» between leaders of faith communities and humanist associations in Europe in [[Strasbourg]] in April 2008,<ref>[https://wcd.coe.int/ViewDoc.jsp?Ref=CM(2008)62&Language=lanEnglish&Ver=original&Site=CM&BackColorInternet=9999CC&BackColorIntranet=FFBB55&BackColorLogged=FFAC75 Council of Europe (2008a) ''Report on Council of Europe 2008 Exchange on the Religious Dimension of Intercultural Dialogue'' (Strasbourg, 8 April 2008), 118th Session of the Committee of Ministers, Strasbourg, 7 May 2008]</ref> and was part of the team which drafted the Recommendation by the Committee of Ministers on teaching about religions and non-religious convictions, published in 2008.<ref>[https://wcd.coe.int//ViewDoc.jsp?Ref=CM/Rec(2008)12&Language=lanEnglish&Ver=original&BackColorInternet=DBDCF2&BackColorIntranet=FDC864&BackColorLogged=FDC864 Council of Europe (2008b) Recommendation CM/Rec (2008) ''12 of the Committee of Ministers to Member States on the Dimension of Religions and Nonreligious Convictions within Intercultural Education'']</ref> In 2006 he conducted a study for the Council of Europe exploring the feasibility of a European educational centre, including studies of religious diversity.<ref>Jackson, R. (2006) ''A ‘Centre of Excellence’ in Education for Democratic Citizenship, Human Rights, Intercultural Education and Education about Religious Diversity: A Feasibility Study, Report for the Council of Europe Committee of Ministers''</ref> The recommendation to initiate an interdisciplinary centre, including intercultural, human rights and citizenship education, with cross-cutting subjects such as religion and history, was taken up by the [[Politics of Norway|Norwegian Government]] and the Council of Europe, and the [[European Wergeland Centre]] opened in Oslo in 2009. Jackson held a Visiting Professorship at [[Oslo University College]] (2009–2012) in order to take on the role of Special Adviser on religious diversity and education at the European Wergeland Centre.<ref>[http://www.theewc.org/Content/Who-we-are/Contacts/Experts/Robert-Jackson The European Wergeland Centre on Jackson]</ref> He continues in the role of Expert Adviser at the Council of Europe and the European Wergeland Centre. From 2011 to 2014 he was vice-chair of a joint Council of Europe and European Wergeland Centre committee given the task of disseminating the 2008 Council of Europe Ministerial recommendation. Jackson wrote the book ''Signposts'' which developed from this work, on behalf of the joint committee. ''Signposts'' was published in English in 2014<ref>Jackson, R. (2014) ''Signposts: Policy and Practice for Teaching about Religions and Non-Religious Worldviews in Intercultural Education''. Strasbourg: Council of Europe Publishing</ref> and has been translated into twelve European languages as well as Arabic.<ref>[http://www.theewc.org/Content/Library/COE-Steering-documents/Recommendations/Signposts-Policy-and-practice-for-teaching-about-religions-and-non-religious-world-views-in-intercultural-education (English text of ''Signposts'' together with Arabic, Dutch, French, German, Greek, Norwegian, Romanian, Russian, Spanish, Swedish and Ukrainian translations; more translations are in preparation, including Italian)]</ref> He is currently a Visiting Professor in the Department of Humanities and Social Sciences Education at [[Stockholm University]], Sweden.<ref name="Stockholm">[http://www.su.se/english/profiles/rjack-1.269657 Presentation of Jackson on Stockholm University's website]</ref>
Jackson also contributed to the ''Toledo Guiding Principles on Teaching about Religions and Beliefs in Public Schools'', published by the Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights of the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]].<ref>[http://www.osce.org/item/28314.html OSCE/ODIHR (2007) ''The Toledo Guiding Principles on Teaching about Religions and Beliefs in Public Schools'' (Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, Warsaw)]</ref>
==International outreach== Beyond his work in Europe, Jackson has contributed to discussions on the place of the study of religions in education in countries including the USA,<ref>Jackson, R. (2005) ‘Rethinking Religious Education and Plurality: Issues in Public Religious Education’, ''Religion & Education'', 32 (1), pp 1–10. (USA)</ref> Canada,<ref>Jackson, R (1999) ‘Multiculturalism and Religious Education’ ''Canadian and International Education'' (Canada), 28 (2), pp 151–80</ref> Japan,<ref>Jackson, R. (2008) «Living with difference through religious and citizenship education: Interpretive and dialogical approaches». In Omori, H. ''Rebuilding Morals Education''. Tokyo: Kyo-Bun-Kan: Research Institute of Aoyama Gakuin University editions. (in Japanese), pp 230–259</ref> South Africa,<ref>Jackson, R. (1996) ‘Re-examining “Religions” and “Culture” in Religious Education’. In W. Weisse (ed) ''Interreligious and Intercultural Education: Methodologies, Conceptions and Pilot Projects in South Africa, Namibia, Great Britain, the Netherlands and Germany''. Münster: Comenius-Institut, pp 11–26</ref> and Australia.<ref>Jackson, R (2003) «Applying the Interpretive Approach in the Classroom: School Based Research and Reflection on Practice». In: ''Journal of Religious Education'' (Australia), 51 (2), 10-13</ref>
==Honours== [[File:Robert «Bob»Jackson and Bjørn Alterhaug.JPG|thumb|260px|Jackson (trombone) and the Norwegian professor and jazz musician [[Bjørn Alterhaug]] (double bass). Trondheim, 2017]] In 1990 Jackson gained an award from the [[Economic and Social Research Council]], which supported the Religious Education and Community Project, studying children from a range of religious backgrounds in two English cities.<ref>Jackson, R. (1991) «The Religious Education and Community Project, Education in Religion». In: ''The Journal of the Scottish Working Party on Religions of the World in Education'', April, 59–62</ref>
In 2010, Jackson was elected Academician (later Fellow) of the [[Academy of Social Sciences]].<ref>[https://www.acss.org.uk/fellow/professor-robert-jackson-facss/ Jackson on AcSS' website]</ref> He was awarded Life Membership of the Association of University Lecturers in Religious Education in July 2013.<ref name="Stockholm"/> In November 2013, he became the 12th recipient of the William Rainey Harper Award from the Religious Education Association of the USA and Canada, joining the ranks of Paulo Freire, Margaret Mead and Marshall McLuhan. The award is presented to ‘outstanding leaders whose work in other fields has had profound impact upon religious education’.<ref>[https://religiouseducation.net/harper Religious Education Association on the award]</ref> A group of Jackson’s former doctoral students produced a special issue of the American journal ''[[Religion & Education]]'' (vol 40, no. 1) and a Routledge book in his honour, both published in 2013.<ref>Miller, J., O'Grady, K. and McKenna, U. (eds) (2013) ''Religion in Education: Innovation in International Research''. New York and London: Routledge</ref>
In March 2017, Jackson was awarded an honorary doctorate (Doc h.c.) By the [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]] (NTNU) for his contribution to religious and intercultural education in Norway and internationally, including his work for the Council of Europe.<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/ntnu-trondheim/sets/72157679314939491 NTNU's photos on Flickr from the conferral]</ref> In October 2017, he was awarded an honorary doctorate by the [[Norwegian School of Theology]] (MF) in Oslo for his contributions to education in Norway and internationally.<ref>[https://vimeo.com/album/4829289/video/239451505 MF's film from the conferral]</ref>
==Jazz and poetry== Jackson has been a jazz musician throughout his career, regarding the music as a complement to his academic pursuits, comparing the eclectic nature and creative development of the interpretive approach to jazz music.<ref>Jackson, R. (2012) «Religious Education and the Arts of Interpretation Revisited». In Ina ter Avest (ed.) ''On the Edge: (Auto)biography and Pedagogical Theories on Religious Education'', pp 57–69. Rotterdam: Sense Publishers</ref> His band, Spicy Jazz, has worked since the 1980s, mainly in the English Midlands. Jackson proposed trumpet player, bandleader, broadcaster and writer, [[Humphrey Lyttelton]] for an honorary doctorate at the University of Warwick, which was awarded in 1987. Lyttelton appeared as a guest with Spicy Jazz and wrote the sleeve note for their recording, ''Coming of Age''.<ref>''Spicy Jazz, Coming of Age'', BSL3131, recorded 27 April 2002, reissued March 2016</ref> Following Humphrey Lyttelton’s death in 2008, Jackson accepted an invitation to become patron of the Humph Trust.<ref>[http://www.humphreylyttelton.com/the-humph-trust/ The Humph Trust website]</ref> Jackson has also played Jazz in Sweden and in Norway, including playing with [[Bjørn Alterhaug]], [[Vigleik Storaas]] and other leading Norwegian jazz musicians.
A further creative interest is poetry, and a selection of Jackson’s poems, together with poems by Dermot Killingley, is published in ''Narrowboat Music''.<ref>Jackson, R. and Killingley, D. (2015) ''Narrowboat Music: Poems of Life''. Newcastle upon Tyne: Grevatt & Grevatt. {{ISBN|9780947722265}}</ref> The book includes a song lyric dedicated to UK jazz trombonist [[Roy Williams (musician)|Roy Williams]], and performed by a trio from Spicy Jazz.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mQblrYCnFo0 The trio from Spicy Jazz (with Jackson) on youtube]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/ces/research/wreru/aboutus/staff/rj/ Jackson on WRERU's website] Retrieved 30 January 2018
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jackson, Robert (1945-)}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Warwick]] [[Category:Educational researchers]] [[Category:British educators]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Wales, Lampeter]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2015}}
'''Skillstreaming''' is a social skills training method introduced by Dr. Arnold P. Goldstein in 1973. It has been widely used in the United States, as well as other countries, in schools, agencies, and institutions serving children and youth. The Skillstreaming programs for early childhood, elementary age, and adolescence are published by the Research Press Publishing Company of [[Champaign, Illinois]].
Behavior theorists, including [[Albert Bandura]] described the processes of modeling, behavioral rehearsal, and reinforcement which are the basis of the Skillstreaming approach. However, rather than emphasizing operant procedures such as prompting and shaping of behaviors, Skillstreaming takes a more [[psychoeducational]] approach, viewing the individual as a person in need of help in the form of skills training.<ref name="MaherZins2014">{{cite book|author1=Charles A Maher|author2=Joseph Zins|author3=Maurice Elias|title=Bullying, Victimization, and Peer Harassment: A Handbook of Prevention and Intervention|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AYfsAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA226|date=25 February 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-78722-8|pages=226–}}</ref> The method provides active and deliberate learning of desirable behaviors to replace less productive behaviors.<ref name="GimpelPeacock2003">{{cite book|author1=Gretchen A. Gimpel|author2=Gretchen Gimpel Peacock|author3=Melissa L. Holland|title=Emotional and Behavioral Problems of Young Children: Effective Interventions in the Preschool and Kindergarten Years|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=usQAb3Y5V2EC&pg=PA80|year=2003|publisher=Guilford Press|isbn=978-1-57230-861-9|pages=80–}}</ref>
==History==
In 1950s and 1960s, the main therapeutic approaches for dealing with inappropriate behavior in individuals were ([[Psychodynamics|psychodynamic]], [[Nondirective Psychotherapy|nondirective]], and [[behavior modification]]). These three types of therapy focused on helping individuals to express their pre-existing effective, satisfying, or healthy behaviors.
After the [[Deinstitutionalisation|deinstitutionalization]] movement of the 1960s resulted in the discharge of large numbers of people from mental health and other institutions into local communities, Arnold P. Goldstein developed Structured Learning Therapy,<ref>Goldstein, A. P. (1973). ''Structured Learning Therapy: Toward a psychotherapy for the poor''. New York: Academic.</ref> the precursor to Skillstreaming, as a practical method of behavioral training. Structured learning methods deal with aggression, withdrawal, and other nonproductive actions as learned behaviors that can be changed by teaching new, alternative skills.
During this time, progressive education and character education,<ref>Chapman, W. E. (1977). ''Roots of character education''. Schenectady, NY: Character Research Press.</ref> supported the teaching of values, morality, emotional functioning and values clarification,<ref>Simon, S. G., Howe, L. W., & Kirschenbaum, H. (1972). ''Values clarification''. New York: Hart.</ref> moral education,<ref>Kohlberg, L. (Ed.). (1973). ''Collected papers on moral development and moral education''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University, Center for Moral Education.</ref> and affective education<ref>Miller, J. P. (1976). ''Humanizing the classroom''. New York: Praeger.</ref>
As well as filling its initial purpose as an intervention for low-income adults deficient in social skills, Skillstreaming has been used with other populations. In the 1980s, Dr. Goldstein’s skills training program, by that time known as Skillstreaming, was adapted to modify aggression and other problematic behaviors in adolescents, <ref name="Evans2009">{{cite book|author=Amy Evans|title=Behavioral and Academic Effects of Skillstreaming the Adolescent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WM9YQwAACAAJ|year=2009|publisher=Education)--Bucknell University}}</ref><ref>[https://www.deepdyve.com/lp/sage/book-review-refusal-skills-preventing-drug-use-in-adolescents-O03M3WRzxl?articleList=%2Fsearch%3Fauthor%3DHoffmann%252CJohn%2BP. "Book Review: Refusal Skills: Preventing Drug Use in Adolescents"]. ''DeepDyve''.</ref> elementary children<ref name="Kohlmann2009">{{cite book|author=Holly L. Kohlmann|title=The Efficacy of Skillstreaming on Elementary-aged Children with Specific Learning Disabilities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qSm6ZwEACAAJ|year=2009|publisher=University of Wisconsin -- La Crosse}}</ref><ref name="Cardenas1998">{{cite book|author=Elizabeth J. Cardenas|title=The Effects of the Skillstreaming Curriculum on the Social Skills of Children with Specific Learning Disabilities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CQyBNwAACAAJ|year=1998|publisher=University of South Florida}}</ref> and preschool and kindergarten children.<ref name="Niehues2006">{{cite book|author=Sara A. Niehues|title=The Effectiveness of Skillstreaming when Used as a Short-term Intervention for Preschool Children|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AZX3NwAACAAJ|year=2006|publisher=Emporia State University|isbn=978-1-109-80553-6}}</ref> The Skillstreaming approach has been employed with elderly adults, child-abusing parents, industrial managers, police officers, and others.<ref name="Low1999">{{cite book|author=Siew Gei Shirley Low|title=Skillstreaming in Predelinquents with and Without Peer Involvement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V933NAAACAAJ|year=1999|publisher=Murdoch University}}</ref>
Evaluative research studies support the efficacy of Skillstreaming and have suggested means for altering and improving its procedures and materials.<ref>Ganz, Jennifer B., [http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/52057554?q&versionId=65002063 "Skillstreaming the Adolescent: New Strategies and Perspectives for Teaching Prosocial Skills.(Review)"] ''Intervention in School & Clinic'', v.36, no.4, 2001 March, p.246 ({{ISSN|1053-4512}}) Sage Publications, Inc.</ref>
==Publications==
Between 1984 and 2012, Goldstein and Ellen McGinnis published a series of books describing the Skillstreaming program, organized into three age groups: early childhood, elementary and adolescent. These volumes integrate the research findings on program efficacy with training recommendations provided by teachers, administrators, youth care workers, and other practitioners who have used Skillstreaming to teach social skills over the years.<ref name="MaherZins2014" /><ref>[http://www.luc.edu/media/lucedu/education/pdfs/Newsltr-ISPA-Aug-2013.pdf "School Based Support Groups"]. ''ISPA Newsletter'', page 10, Volume 35 Number 1,August 2013.</ref><ref name="Losey2012">{{cite book|author=Butch Losey|title=Bullying, Suicide, and Homicide: Understanding, Assessing, and Preventing Threats to Self and Others for Victims of Bullying|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DHqMAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA83|date=28 March 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-19469-7|pages=83–}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.skillstreaming.com/ Skillstreaming Home Page] * [http://www.researchpress.com/pdf/5187-research.pdf Annotated bibliography of Skillstreaming research] * [http://www.researchpress.com/ Research Press Publishing Company]
[[Category:Pedagogy]]

Astilleroscadiz.buques.org</ref>([[Euros|€]]49,220)<ref>[http://www.exteriores.gob.es/Embajadas/WASHINGTON/en/Noticias/Documents/FOLLETO%20INGLES%20nuevo%20dise%C3%B1o.pdf History summary of the ship] ''Juan Sebastián de Elcano''</ref> |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched = 5 March 1927 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship |Ship honours= |Ship captured= |Ship fate= |Ship status= Active |Ship notes=training ship |Ship badge=[[File:Coat of Arms of Juan Sebastián Elcano A-71.svg|103px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship type= |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement=3673 tons |Ship tons burthen= |Ship length={{convert|113|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|13.11|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship height={{convert|48.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship draught= |Ship draft={{convert|7|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship power= |Ship propulsion= |Ship sail plan=four-masted barquentine; 21 sails, total sail area of {{convert|2,870|m2|abbr=on}}<ref>[http://personales.mundivia.es/medusa/detalles.htm Technical details] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125100702/http://personales.mundivia.es/medusa/detalles.htm |date=2010-11-25 }}</ref> |Ship speed=*max {{convert|13|kn}} engine *{{convert|17.5|kn}} sail |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship complement=300 sailors, 90 midshipmen |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=2 × 57 mm ceremonial gun mounts |Ship armour= |Ship notes=Line art of ''Juan Sebastián de Elcano'' [[File:Spanish tallship Elcano.png|220px|center|Line art of ''Juan Sebastián de Elcano'']] }} |} '''''Juan Sebastián de Elcano''''' is a [[training ship]] for the Royal [[Spanish Navy]]. It is a four-masted topsail, steel-hulled [[barquentine]] ([[schooner barque]]). At {{convert|113|m|ft}} long, it is the third-largest [[tall ship]] in the world, and is the sailing vessel that has sailed the furthest, covering more than {{convert|2,000,000|nmi|lk=in}} in its history.
It is named after Spanish explorer [[Juan Sebastián Elcano]], captain of [[Ferdinand Magellan]]'s last exploratory fleet and the man who completed the first circumnavigation of the world. The ship also carries the Elcano [[coat of arms]], which was granted to the family by Emperor Charles I following Elcano's return in 1522 from Magellan's global expedition. The coat of arms is a terraqueous globe with the motto "Primus Circumdedisti Me" (meaning: "First to [[circumnavigate]] me").
==Build and design== 'Juan Sebastián de Elcano' was built in 1927 in [[Cadiz, Spain]], and its hull was designed by the naval architect Mr C E Nicholson of Camper and Nicholsons Ltd of [[Southampton]]. Constructed by Echevarrieta y Larrinaga shipyard<ref>Sailing Ship Rigs and Rigging, H A Underhill, p.50</ref> in Cadiz. After the proclamation of the [[Second Spanish Republic]] in April 1931 the ship became part of the [[Spanish Republican Navy]].
In 1933 under Commander [[Salvador Moreno Fernández]]'s order, a series of improvements were made to the ship and the bronze plate with the [[Latin language]] inscription ''Tu Primus Circumdedisti Me'' was placed near the prow. At the time of the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|coup of July 1936]] ''Juan Sebastián Elcano'' was at [[Ferrol, Galicia|Ferrol]], a harbor that had been taken by the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist faction]]. Its plans were used twenty-five years later to construct its [[Chile]]an sail training vessel sister ship [[Esmeralda (BE-43)|''Esmeralda'']] in 1952-1954.
==Maiden voyage== Its first voyage was sea testing between April and July that year from Cádiz to [[Malaga]], with [[King Alfonso XIII]] on board as a passenger, and then on to [[Sevilla]], [[Las Palmas]], [[Tenerife]], [[San Sebastián]], Cádiz, [[São Vicente, Cape Verde]], [[Montevideo]], Buenos Aires, Cape Town, [[Adelaide]], [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]], Suva, San Francisco, California, [[Balboa, Panama]], [[Havana]], [[New York City]], Cádiz.<ref>[http://www.exteriores.gob.es/Embajadas/WASHINGTON/en/Noticias/Documents/FOLLETO%20INGLES%20nuevo%20dise%C3%B1o.pdf History summary of the ship] ''Juan Sebastián de Elcano''</ref>
== Naval Commanders of Juan Sebastián Elcano == Commanders that have been in charge of ''Juan Sebastián Elcano'' for crossings and instruction.<ref>[http://www.armada.mde.es/ArmadaPortal/page/Portal/ArmadaEspannola/buques_superficie/prefLang_es/15_Buque_escuela--01_El_cano_en#Comandantes. Relación de Comandantes de J. S. de Elcano en sus cruceros de instrucción|autor.] Ministerio de Defensa|fechaacceso</ref>

Cristóbal González-Aller y Acebal. 24 June 1935 * Fernando Meléndez Bojart. 15 December * Pedro Sans Torres. 20 December 1940 * Camilo Carrero Blanco. 17 January 1942 * Antonio Blanco García. 24 García. 15 July 1952 * José Yusty Pita. 19 August 1953 * José Ramón González López. 20 July 1955 * Miguel Domingo Sotelo. 27 August 1958 * José Díaz Cuñado. 26 September 1960 * Teodoro de Leste y ==See also== * [[Fernando Villaamil]], and his [[circumnavigation]] in 1892-1894 commanding the ''Nautilus'' training ship. * [[Ferrol, Spain|Ferrol]] * [[Escuela Naval Militar|Spanish Naval Academy]] In modern times, Institution where the Spanish Armada (i.e.: [[Spanish Navy]]) officers and other personnel receive their education. * [[Escuela Naval Militar|''El Galatea'']] (also known as ''[[Glenlee (ship)|Glenlee]]'') From 1922 till 1969 she was the [[Tall ship|Training Tall Ship]] for the [[Spanish Navy]] in [[Ferrol, Galicia|Ferrol]] (North-western [[Spain]]). * [[El Club Naval de Ferrol]] Originally designed for the amusement of the [[Spanish Navy|Spanish Navy personnel and their families]] posted to the Naval Station of [[Ferrol, Galicia|Ferrol]]. * [[Structure of the Spanish Navy in the 21st century]] * [[List of large sailing vessels]] * [[List of schooners]]

revision.comment: Jesuits schools are not franchises that display jesuit logo
revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name =St. Peter's Kubatana | native_name = | logo = | logo_size = 180px | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | motto = | streetaddress = | city = High Glen Rd., [[Glen Norah, Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]] | state = | province = | country = | type = [[Jesuit]], [[Catholic church|Catholic]] | denomination = | established = {{Start date and age| 1963 }} | status = | dean = | administrator = |rector = | director = Mr. Wushe (technical school) | principal = Br. Dominic Shoniwa, SJ | headmaster = Mr. Makimeke | staff = | teaching_staff = | grades = | gender = | athletics = | mascot = | nickname = | accreditation = | national_ranking = |publication = | newspaper = | yearbook = | affiliations = <!-- Localización --> | website = [http://www.ajol.info/index.php/ajsw/article/viewFile/127545/117070 AJOL ] | picture = | picture_caption = | affiliation = | assst_admin = | president = | asst principal = | enrollment = 1,051 | tuition =US $150 per term | campus = | colors = | free_label1 = | free_text1 = | free_label2 = |free_text2 = | free_label3 = | free_text3 = }} '''St. Peter's Kubatana''' in [[Glen Norah]], [[Zimbabwe]], includes both a secondary school and technical vocational training. It is situated in a high-density suburb of [[Harare]], and was founded by the [[Society of Jesus]] in 1963.
== History == In 1963 the [[Jesuit]] parish in the present [[Mbare, Harare|Mbare]] area of Harare opened St. Peter’s Community Secondary School (SPCSS) for students engulfed in poverty.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QdmpAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA81&lpg=PA81&dq=St+Peter's+Kubatana+Secondary+school,+Highfield,+Harare,&source=bl&ots=V8BTLgHdvX&sig=uhM3wFBIN-QdvlE-pEfs5tyiQuQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjd5K6MtozRAhUr9IMKHWkOCFoQ6AEIOTAE#v=onepage&q=St%20Peter's%20Kubatana%20Secondary%20school,%20Highfield,%20Harare,&f=false|title=TRIALS AND TRIUMPHS IN ADVERSITY: The Chronicles of a Zimbabwean township up-bringing and the Diaspora Saga|last=Vambe|first=Stanley A.|date=2013-08-27|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=9781483678535|language=en}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=January 2018}}</ref> At the time secondary schools were provided for only the top 12% of primary leavers. SPCSS enrolled 80 students out of 250 applicants, for a two-year course leading to the External Junior Certificate. It used the St. Peter’s Primary School classrooms after the primary students finished their day.
A training school for social workers, the School of Social Service, began operations in the Jesuit parish in the mid-1960s. It later became the School of Social Work (SSW), a degree-awarding department of the University of Zimbabwe. The first premises of SSW were the defunct Morgan High School, and SPCSS was for a time accommodated there also. But this was found to be against the [[apartheid]] policy of the government, since SSW was mixed racial and SPCSS all-black. A closed primary school facility in the new Kambazuma township was made available for SPCSS. In the mid-1960s local volunteers were joined by volunteers from Stonyhurst College in England, who were taking a year off for service before going to the university, to work in these Jesuit schools. In 1968 technical courses were introduced to SPCSS by a Stonyhurst engineering student, and this focus has persisted in the technical school. The high school was to grow to 1051 students and cover through [[sixth-form]].
In the 1970s Kambuzuma’s population was growing and the primary school buildings were reclaimed for their original purpose. The secondary school was resituated on a 10-hectare site in [[Glen Norah, Harare]], and SPCSS took its present name St. Peter’s Kubatana, Kubatana being a Shona word encompassing notions of mutual help and co-operation. Facilities include an administration block and Jesuit residence.<ref>''African Journal of Social Work'' {{Cite web|url=http://www.jesuitsandfriends.org.uk/Previous%20Articles/JF59/happy%2040th/happy%2040th.html|title=Jesuits and Friends - Society of Jesus|website=www.jesuitsandfriends.org.uk|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ajol.info/index.php/ajsw/article/viewFile/127545/117070|title=Setting Up St. Peter's School|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=24 December 2016}}</ref> The high school has, by one account, been ranked as fourth best high school in Harare.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://tripsuccor.com/zimbabwe/places/st-peters-kubatana-high-school-high-school-harare|title=St Peters Kubatana High School and 10+ more top High Schools near Harare|work=Glopoi|access-date=2017-08-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
St. Peters Mbare parish helps support orphaned and vulnerable children. A scholarship fund has been set up to subsidize the fees for 85 primary and secondary school children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jesuitszimbabwe.co.zw/index.php/2015-01-05-16-44-03/in-touch/174-2015/intouch-no-65/451-st-peter-s-mbare-parish-reaches-out-to-orphans|title=St Peter’s Mbare parish reaches out to orphans|website=Jesuits Zimbabwe - The Zimbabwe Province of the Society of Jesus|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref>
== Programs == St. Peter's Kubatana Training Centre in [[Highfield, Harare]], has launched an arts and culture programme and helps students to pursue arts as a career. It also assists local artists with further training and offers space for work and for exhibitions. The technical school at St. Peter’s Kubatanahas has expanded to include welding, sewing, motor mechanics, automobile and mechanical engineering, construction and civil engineering, and woodworking.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mhtestd.gov.zw/index.php/courses|title=Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education - Courses|website=www.mhtestd.gov.zw|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jesuitszimbabwe.co.zw/index.php/2015-01-05-16-44-03/in-touch/154-2014/no-41/332-st-peter-s-kubatana-launches-arts-and-culture-department|title=St Peter’s Kubatana Launches Arts and Culture Department|last=Taruva|first=Fortunate|website=Jesuits Zimbabwe - The Zimbabwe Province of the Society of Jesus|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref> Technical school graduates have risen to 120 in a year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jesuitszimbabwe.co.zw/index.php/contact/701-120-graduate-from-st-peters-kubatana-industrial-training-college|title=120 grads|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jesuitszimbabwe.co.zw/index.php/contact/701-120-graduate-from-st-peters-kubatana-industrial-training-college|title=Enrollment|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 December 2016}}</ref> St. Peter's is also a part of a [[UNESCO-UNEVOC|UN]] effort to strengthen vocational and technical education in Zimbabwe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unevoc.unesco.org/go.php?q=World+TVET+Database&ct=ZWE|title=UNESCO-UNEVOC World TVET Database|website=www.unevoc.unesco.org|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref>
Students from St Peter's won the Shoko Hub Unconference category of best idea on creative campaigns to increase citizen engagement through use of a social platform to act as the voice for school students in telling their own stories. The conference encourages creativity, innovation, and action and includes speakers from around Africa and from Europe on topics like new media, writing for the web, increasing social engagement, and the creative economy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pachikoro.co.zw/2015/10/st-peters-kubatana-wins-hub-unconference-award/|title=St Peters Kubatana wins Hub Unconference award {{!}} Pachikoro|website=www.pachikoro.co.zw|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref> The facebook page IoT Makerspace St-Peters Mbare Internet-Society has been maintained by local students who were the beneficiaries of St. Peter's school of social services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kdnuggets.com/2016/10/top-blogger-interview-ajit-jaokar-iot-data-science.html|title=KDnuggets Top Blogger: An Interview with Ajit Jaokar, on IoT and Data Science|website=www.kdnuggets.com|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref>
The school boasts the "best known" [[marimba]] band in Zimbabwe.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=br7n-gvkWvIC&pg=PA375&lpg=PA375&dq=st.+peters+kubatana&source=bl&ots=1T3uEaWCaC&sig=QiMogy7QMAoAM7hOxgAmyzYbuYI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwim9r-V_pHRAhWp24MKHR19DT44KBDoAQg8MAc#v=onepage&q=st.%20peters%20kubatana&f=false|title=The Rough Guide to Zimbabwe|last=McCrea|first=Barbara|last2=Pinchuck|first2=Tony|date=2000-01-01|publisher=Rough Guides|year=|isbn=9781858285320|location=|pages=375|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/4642267-St-Peters-Kubatana-Marimba-Band|title=St Peter's Kubatana Marimba Band|website=Discogs|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.delcampe.net/en_GB/collectables/music-instruments/vinyl-records-world-music/lp-st-peter-s-kubatana-marimba-band-same-africa-1980-ex-287096557.html|title=* LP * ST PETER'S KUBATANA MARIMBA BAND - SAME (Africa 1980 EX-!!!) {{!}} For sale on Delcampe|website=Delcampe - The Marketplace for collectors|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref> Dancers from the school have attracted international attention.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://spiked.co.zw/?p=703|title=US dancer for Jibilika finals {{!}} spiked|website=spiked.co.zw|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref> Students from the school were also privileged to represent Zimbabwe at an African climate change conference in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://catholicclimatemovement.global/cynesa-expands-in-zimbabwe-and-botswana/|title=CYNESA expands in 2015 {{!}} The Global Catholic Climate Movement|website=catholicclimatemovement.global|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cynesa.org/climate-change/|title=Climate Change Toolkit|date=2015-02-10|newspaper=Catholic Youth Network for Environmental Sustainability in Africa|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Coord|17|54|19.5|S|30|58|59.77|E|display=title}}

revision.comment: /* top */[[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/PrimeBOT 29|Task 29]] - removal of deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox person]] (+ genfixes)
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name=Stephen H. Gloucester |image=Stephen Gloucester Portrait.jpg |caption= |birth_date=1802 |birth_place= |death_date=May 21, 1850 |death_place=[[Reading, Pennsylvania]], USA}}
'''Stephen Gloucester''' (1802 – 1850) was among the primary organizers for the [[Underground Railroad]] in [[Philadelphia]] and the founder of The First African Presbyterian Church at Girard Avenue and 42nd Street in Philadelphia, which had 123 members by 1811.<ref name=abolitionistpapers>{{cite book|title=The Black Abolitionist Papers|last=Ripley|first=Peter C.|year=1991|publisher=UNC Press|isbn=0-8078-1926-3|pages=552}}</ref>
==Slavery== Gloucester was one of the four sons of [[John Gloucester]]. Stephen was born a slave in [[Tennessee]], his father paid $400 for Stephen's freedom when he was 12 years of age.
==Community organizer== Between 1820 and 1840, Reverend Gloucester ran a school for black children and established a reading room for black adults. He organized the Leavitt Anti-Slavery Society and encouraged black churches to start similar groups, and was one of eight black pastors who founded the American and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society. In 1838, he became a co-publisher and co-proprietor of the [[The Colored American (New York City)|Colored American]]. He became the pastor of the [[Second African Presbyterian]] after its previous pastor died. A mob destroyed Second African Presbyterian in the 1842 race riots.
==Controversy==
In 1844, Gloucester became the founding pastor at Lombard Street Central Presbyterian Church - a church that was formed after the congregation of Second Presbyterian split into two factions. This schism with other activists led Gloucester to concentrate on his church, which moved into the white, Greek Revival-style building on the 800 block of Lombard upon its completion in 1848. The church eventually dropped the "street" in its name and became known as Lombard Central Presbyterian.
Frederick Douglass is said to have called Gloucester "one of the vilest traitors to his race that ever lived."<ref>The Black Abolitionist Papers, VOLUME III, The United States, 1830-1846, Editor: C. Peter Ripley, P. 199, section: "Address by Watkins, Moore, and White" [https://www.scribd.com/doc/144975991/C-Peter-Ed-Ripley-the-Black-Abolitionist-Papers-Vol-III-the-United-States-1830-1846-1991]</ref>
==Death and burial site== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Stephen Gloucester Burial Site.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The church which once held the missing burial marker of Rev. Gloucester.]] --> In 1850, while on a church-related trip to Reading, Gloucester died of pneumonia. Gloucester's congregation buried him in a brick vault in the front of the building he had raised money to construct.
There they placed a marble obelisk, inscribed: :''Rev. Stephen Henry Gloucester'' :''First Pastor of the Lombard St. Central Presbyterian Church'' :''Died May 21, 1850'' :''Aged 48'' :''Erected by the Congregation and Citizens among whom he labored, as an expression of esteem and affection for him – a devoted and successful minister of Jesus :Christ.''
In 1880, Ann Gloucester died, and her remains were placed with her husband in the brick vault.
At some point since an 1895 photograph was taken, the large obelisk that marked the Gloucesters' grave went missing.
In 1939, the congregation outgrew their original church, which is on the [[National Register of Historic Places]], and moved to a historic former Quaker meeting house on Powelton Avenue in West Philadelphia.
In the summer of 2008, a couple who had bought the property was in the process of converting the worn-out structure into a {{convert|10000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} luxury home they hope to sell for $4.95 million. Workers hit a piece of slate which turned out to be his brick tomb. On Friday November 21, 2008, his remains were found. Mooney, an archeologist, said in an email Saturday, November 22, 2008, that all evidence at the site backs up the documentary evidence that the vault contained the remains of the Gloucesters and Winrow. Forensic details are forthcoming.<ref name=planphilly>{{cite web|title=Finding Reverend Gloucester|url=http://www.planphilly.com/node/4551|date=2008-11-23|author=Kellie Patrick Gates}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gloucester, Stephen H.}} [[Category:Activists for African-American civil rights]] [[Category:Community organizing]] [[Category:Nonviolence advocates]] [[Category:1802 births]] [[Category:1850 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:19th-century African-American activists]] [[Category:Underground Railroad people]] [[Category:African-American abolitionists]] [[Category:American slaves]]

{{italic title}} '''''The Inner World of Aphasia''''' is a 1968 [[Medical training in the US|medical training]] film by co-directors Edward Feil and Naomi Feil of Edward Feil Productions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/2015-additions-to-the-national-film-registry/14/|title=2015 additions to the National Film Registry|date=2016-09-05|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en}}</ref> It portrays patients suffering from [[aphasia]] and follows their experiences through their recoveries. Notable for its innovative artistic direction and empathetic approach to patients with aphasia, the film was added to the [[National Film Registry]] in 2015.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.loc.gov/item/prn-15-216/2015-national-film-registry-ghostbusters-gets-the-call/2015-12-16/|title=2015 National Film Registry: "Ghostbusters" Gets the Call|work=The Library of Congress|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en}}</ref>
== Plot == The film follows Marge Nelson (portrayed by Naomi Feil), a nurse who treats patients suffering from aphasia. Marge is overworked and unsympathetic towards her patients, experiencing frustration at their behavior and apparent inability to communicate.
Upon having an accident and suffering brain damage, Marge herself experiences aphasia and undergoes treatment at the same hospital where she previously worked. While struggling to deal with the emotions around her trauma and new issues with processing information and communicating, Marge also discovers a startling lack of empathy from hospital staff and therapists treating her.
Marge finds a new friend in a second patient who is suffering from aphasia. The film shows us that, like Marge, this second patient has also experienced a lack of empathy from others, except in his case it is his family members who are unable to understand his illness.
Through this new friendship and her own determination, Marge changes the emotional direction of her life and takes the first steps towards her recovery.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1968|title=CINE/68|jstor=20686999|journal=Journal of the University Film Association|volume=20| issue = 3|pages=75}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Diller|first=Leonard|date=January 1969|title=The Treatment of Aphasia: A Film|url=http://access.portico.org/stable?au=phzjr78wh|journal=PsycCRITIQUES|publisher=American Psychological Association|volume=14|pages=43–44|via=Portico}}</ref>
== Reception == ''The Inner World of Aphasia'' was praised by contemporary sources for its attention to [[patient experience]], particularly for drawing attention to the ways in which patients treated for aphasia in the 1960s were dehumanized by hospital staff and family members.<ref name=":2" />
Compared to other media portrayals of aphasia the time, ''The Inner World of'' ''Aphasia'' was unique for its focus on portraying "the complex subjective feel of what it is like to be an aphasic."<ref name=":2" /> Its use of [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]], optical distortions, and audio editing techniques were noted by medical professionals as accurately conveying the experience of a person suffering from aphasia (such as [[hemiplegia]] and [[hemianopsia]]).<ref name=":2" />
== Awards and Recognition == In 1968, ''The Inner World of Aphasia'' received the Golden Eagle from The Council on International Non-Theatrical Events (CINE), the organization's highest honor.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
In 1969, ''[[American Journal of Nursing|The American Journal of Nursing]]'' included ''The Inner World of Aphasia'' on its list of films screened by the [[American Nurses Association]] / National League of Nurses Film Committee and recommended for screening to nurses and nursing students.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=April 1969|title=Films Screened|jstor=3453849|journal=The American Journal of Nursing|volume=69| issue = 4|pages=854}}</ref>
In 2015, ''The Inner World of Aphasia'' was added to the [[National Film Registry]], a selection of films noted as worthy of preservation by the United States National Film Preservation Board.<ref name=":0" />

{{Underlinked|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox video game | collapsible = | state = | italic title = | title = Tooth Invaders | image = File:Tooth_Invaders.jpg | alt = | caption = VIC-20 cartridge | developer = [[Commodore Business Machines|Commodore International]] | publisher = [[Commodore Business Machines|Commodore International]] | series = | engine = | platforms = [[Commodore VIC-20|VIC-20]] (original), [[Commodore 64]] | released = 1981: VIC-20
1982: C64 | genre = Action, Educational | modes = }} '''Tooth Invaders''' is a video game released by [[Commodore Business Machines|Commodore International]] for its [[Commodore VIC-20|VIC-20]] home computer in 1981 and later for the [[Commodore 64|C64]] in 1982. It was developed in association with Camelot Marketing Group in order to positively reinforce the pros of brushing, flossing, and healthy dental care.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2nQdAQAAMAAJ|title=Quintessence International, Dental Digest|date=1983-01-01|publisher=Buch- und Zeitschriften-Verlag "Die Quintessenz,"|language=en}} Seen as a fun way to teach children the importance of dental care, players fight as "Plaqueman" to fight plaque using a toothbrush and dental floss.{{cn|date=August 2016}} It was also made in association with the [[American Dental Association]], released during National Dental Month, and supported by dentists.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JVlWAAAAMAAJ|title=Microcomputing|date=1983-01-01|publisher=Wayne Green, Incorporated|language=en}} ==Gameplay== Using a toothbrush and dental floss, the player must keep the teeth clean while avoiding contact with the Plaque Germ, known as "D.K". If D.K. comes into contact with the player, this will result in loss of one life. The brush needs tooth paste to work so the player must apply tooth paste. Floss is used for the space between teeth. If the teeth aren't cleaned properly and start to decay a warning bell sounds. Eventually the tooth will disappear, reflecting tooth loss. If a tooth is completely cleaned, a brief musical score will play and the teeth will change colors repeatedly. If the player comes into contact with D.K. at this time, the Plaque Germ will disappear for a time. Losing all lives or having four teeth lost will end the game.{{cite web|title=Full text of "Tooth Invaders Manual"|url=https://archive.org/stream/ToothInvadersManual/Tooth_Invaders_Manual_djvu.txt|website=archive.org|accessdate=23 August 2016}} == Reception == ''Ready: A Commodore 64 Retrospective'' described it as a "simple game", a "standout" of Commodore's first generation of educational software, and a "pioneer in the serious games and games for health fields".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ecuoBQAAQBAJ|title=Ready: A Commodore 64 Retrospective|last=Dillon|first=Roberto|date=2014-12-03|publisher=Springer|isbn=9789812873415|language=en}} However, the book also noted that the game aged relatively quickly due to the rapid improvement in game quality in the following years. ''Microcomputing'' considered the game an "excellent" example of how computer software could be used educationally to create behavioural change.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JVlWAAAAMAAJ|title=Microcomputing|date=1983-01-01|publisher=Wayne Green, Incorporated|language=en}} Games Village wrote that behind the patently idiotic facade, it instead proves to be a balanced and enjoyable puzzle game.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gamesvillage.it/retro/news/1835183/tooth-invaders-ligiene-orale-ai-tempi-dei-pixel/|title=Tooth Invaders: l'igiene orale ai tempi dei pixel • GamesVillage.it|language=it-IT|access-date=2016-08-31}} The game was included in the "Open Wide! Tooth Toys That Made Us Smile" exhibit at the [[National Museum of Dentistry]].{{Cite journal|date=2011-04-03|title=Be Captivated By The Charm City ; Head South To Baltimore, And Your Family Will Find Plenty Of Reasons To Smile.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-28349438.html}}{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/yourlife/parenting-family/2010-12-28-ToothToys28_ST_N.htm|title='Open Wide!' exhibit displays toys kids have cut their teeth on - USATODAY.com|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com|access-date=2016-08-31}} ==See also== *''[[Plaque Attack]]'' for the Atari 2600 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://archive.org/stream/ToothInvadersManual/Tooth_Invaders_Manual_djvu.txt Text of the game manual] *{{lemon64 game|id=2677|name=Tooth Invaders}} [[Category:1981 video games]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:Commodore VIC-20 games]] [[Category:Educational video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] {{action-videogame-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox academic division | name = University of Ghana Medical School | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | motto_eng = | established = {{start date and age|1962}} | closed = | type = [[Medical school]] | parent = [[University of Ghana]], [[Legon]] | affiliation = | city = [[Accra]] | state = [[Greater Accra Region]] | country = [[Ghana]] | coor = | dean = | director = | head_label = | head = | faculty = | students = ~1000 | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | alumni = | symbol = | website = {{URL|http://smd.ug.edu.gh//}} | logo = | footnotes = | embedded = }}
The '''University of Ghana Medical School''' also '''UGMS''' is the [[Medical School|medical school]] of [[Ghana]]'s first public research institution, the [[University of Ghana]]. It is currently located at the [[Korle Bu Teaching Hospital]] in [[Accra]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://smd.ug.edu.gh/|title=Home {{!}} School of Medicine and Dentistry|website=smd.ug.edu.gh|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327164649/http://smd.ug.edu.gh/|archivedate=2018-03-27|df=}}</ref> The medical school was first planned in 1919, but took its first students in 1962.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://ugms.edu.gh/index.php/about-us/history-of-ugms |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150616162040/http://ugms.edu.gh/index.php/about-us/history-of-ugms |archivedate=2015-06-16 |df= }}</ref><ref name=":1" />
== History == The plan to set up a medical school on the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] was drawn up after the establishment of the [[Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital|Korle Bu Hospital]] in 1919 by the British Governor at the time, Sir [[Gordon Guggisberg|Frederick Gordon Guggisberg]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The idea was abandoned after Guggisberg left office.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> There was renewed interest in this venture in 1951.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> At the behest of the Gold Coast colonial administration and the [[University College of the Gold Coast]], a technical team from the [[University of London]] visited the Gold Coast to assess the scheme and specifications for staffing and facilities that would be required fully operationalise a medical school.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1952, a government-approved commission recommended the postponement of the establishment of medical school indefinitely.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1955, the issue was revisited and the colonial government invited the [[University College of the Gold Coast]] and the [[Kumasi College of Technology]] to examine the options to start a medical school.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> It was decided medical courses would be introduced in a step-by-step fashion, as originally espoused by the [[University of London]] delegation in 1951.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1956, the University Council Committee under the leadership of the institution’s first principal, [[David Mowbray Balme|David Balme]], was formed to suggest other avenues for founding the school.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The recommendations of this committee included an annual enrollment of 20 to 25 students, establishment of four pre-clinical departments at the [[University of Ghana|University College of the Gold Coast]], [[Legon]] and the upgrade of the [[Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital|Korle Bu Hospital]] to a teaching hospital with its autonomous management board.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> By 1960, the year Ghana became a republic, there was still no pathway for implementation as Korle Bu was not equipped for clinical training and funds were unavailable for its expansion. The Nkrumah government sought technical and financial assistance from the [[Kennedy Administration|Kennedy administration.]]<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The US government appointed a team led by physician, Paul Connerlly to review all previous assessments.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> This team suggested the establishment of a ''National Medical and Health Training Centre'' under which the medical school would function.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The government accepted these recommendations.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1962, the [[United States Agency for International Development|US Agency for International Development]] (USAID) recommended that the National Medical and Health Training Centre should have these subsidiaries: a medical school, a school of nursing; a dental school; a school of medical technology; a post graduate school; a research facilities centre.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
It was planned that the medical school would be financially independent with its own council.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> However, the [[University of Ghana]] would be its parent institution and would award its medical degrees.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The suggested curriculum would be American-based even though the Ghanaian education was modelled on the British university system.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> To streamline these differences, admitted sixth formers were to go through a two-year pre-medical science course prior to the actual medical training. In October 1962, the foundation class of 51 premedical students were admitted to the University of Ghana.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Within a year of the programme, the American Dean informed the government that he was unable to find lecturers in the basic sciences. In February 1964, Ghana’s first president decided to wholly rely on domestic sources of funding and manpower to establish the full medical school. A study tour by [[Alexander Kwapong]], [[Charles Odamtten Easmon]] and [[E. A. Badoe]] at then newly established [[University of Lagos]] and [[University of Ibadan]] medical schools, was used as a basis for the feasibility studies.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
In October 1964, 41 students enrolled in the preclinical training with a group of indigenous doctors being their lecturers.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Most courses were drawn from [[gross anatomy]] and [[histology]], taught by J.K.M Quartey and F. N. L. Engmann.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Surgeons and pathologists at government hospitals in Accra taught on an [[Adjunct professor|adjunct]] basis.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Later, the department of physiology was started by H. H. Philips while biochemistry was started by B. Y. A. Andoh as part of the curriculum that included [[basic sciences]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Teaching in paraclinical departments commenced in April 1966 while those in clinical departments started in April 1967.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The [[professoriate]] was almost entirely Ghanaian. The pioneering class of 39 medical students graduated in June 1969. Expatriate lecturers were recruited at the end of the first year. By the end of 1968, the Ghana medical school had become a semi-autonomous school under the University of Ghana with functions identical to other faculties of the university.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> It assumed a new name, the ''University of Ghana Medical School'' and its own Executive Council and School Board were assembled. The school held landmark events to celebrate and its silver jubilee in 1987 and fortieth anniversary in 2002.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
The self-accounting administration was subordinate to both the board and the executive council.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> As a university faculty, a Dean provided academic and administrative leadership, assisted by a Vice Dean and an Executive Secretary.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The first Executive Secretary of the medical school was C. K. Gbeho and Deborah Boafoh was the first Administrative Secretary.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The medical school now operates through seventeen departments, namely departments of [[anatomy]], [[biochemistry]], [[physiology]], [[chemical pathology]], [[haematology]], [[Microbiology|mircobiology]], [[pathology]], [[pharmacology]], [[Anesthesia|anaesthesia]], [[Pediatrics|paediatrics]], [[community health]], [[medicine]] and [[Therapy|therapeutics]], [[obstetrics and gynaecology]], [[psychiatry]], [[radiology]] and [[surgery]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Four out every five faculty at the school are alumni.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
The school had eight department in its early years. Paraclinical Departments and department heads consisted of the following: * Department of Pharmacology led by R. Lewis with J. Blukoo Allotey as his deputy * Department of Pathology led by F. W. N. Laing * Department of Microbiology, led by S. N. Afoakwa * Department of Surgery, led by [[Charles Odamtten Easmon]] * Department of Medicine, led by S. R. A. Dodu * Department of Paediatrics, led by Yaw Asirifi * Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, led by K. K. Bentsi-Enchill * Department of Community Health, led by [[Fred T. Sai]]
== School mission == The medical school’s mission focuses on learning, research and knowledge dissemination in the national and global context. Specifically, the college aims to train:
*''“A broad-based generalist practitioner with sufficient grounding for subsequent specialization'' *''A practitioner functionally attuned to and therefore responding aptly to the needs and exigencies of his/her environment. He/she shall attain internationally accepted standards''.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> *''A practitioner who has participated in health care delivery while under instruction and therefore cognizant of the problems of health delivery and also an individual who accepts responsibility for self-learning and therefore readily responsive to the call for continuing education, and advocate for community health needs.”''<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Learning environment == === Curriculum === The school curriculum has gone through periodic reviews in line with national health needs and contemporary trends in medical education.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1992, a biomedical science bachelor’s degree was introduced to be conferred at the end of the para-clinical sciences course and is now a prerequisite for clinical training.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The length of the medical course was reduced from seven and a half years to six year, inclusive of a year-long premedical course.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> A new curriculum was introduced in 2009 and two classes were simultaneously admitted: [[secondary school]] students and bachelor degree holders in the natural sciences for the Graduate Entry Medical Programme (GEMP).<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://www.ugms.edu.gh/|title=Homepage|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=UGMS|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013035209/http://www.ugms.edu.gh/|archivedate=13 October 2014|deadurl=yes|accessdate=15 October 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://www.ugms.edu.gh/index.php/gemp|title=GEMP|publisher=UGMS|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130813151018/http://ugms.edu.gh/index.php/gemp|archivedate=13 August 2013|deadurl=yes|accessdate=26 February 2015|df=}}</ref> The GEMP is an integrated four-year medical degree.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> A clinical skills and simulation centre was also established in 2009 to enhance clinical skills training. The Ghanaian government also provided a high-capacity medical library for the UGMS through budgetary support and GET Fund allocation.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== Student enrollment === The first batch of students in 1964 had 41 students.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> By 1973, the number had risen to 53 students.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1999, 94 students matriculated at the medical school. With two streams in 2006/07, intake rose to 195 per year.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Between 2000 and 2006, student enrolled per annum effectively doubled from about 100 to 200.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 2011, enrollment was 150 per year. The school strives to achieve gender parity in its admissions, with women guaranteed a minimum of 25% of the incoming class.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=http://ugms.edu.gh/index.php/about-us/history-of-ugms|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150616162040/http://ugms.edu.gh/index.php/about-us/history-of-ugms|archivedate=2015-06-16|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2015-05-19|df=}}</ref> Women intake in the school’s first class was 3 which increased steadily over the years to 71 out a total of 154 students who matriculated in 2011. This represents an increase of 2367 percentage points. Between 1969 and 2012, the medical school produced 2752 physicians, consisting of 2083 men and 669 women.
In its early days, the school reserved 5% of spots to foreign students from African countries without medical schools. From 1999, the population of international students from around the globe has been pegged at 20%. Student enrollment stood at 802 in the 2006/07.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In the 2010/11 academic year, the medical school had an incoming class of 150, and rising, at least a quarter of which are women.<ref name=":4" />
=== Institutional challenges === In the 1980s, due to an [[Recession|economic downturn]] from the [[Structural Adjustment Programme|structural adjustment programme]] in Ghana, the school faced an exodus of its faculty to institutions abroad which led to a reduction in the student intake.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> There is also an “internal brain drain” as result of a wage gap between clinical teaching staff and consultants in the Ministry of Health whose compensation far exceed that of the UGMS professors.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The physical space for clinical training and research is also very limited.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> For example, the Basic Sciences Building which houses 200 students was originally built to accommodate a quarter of that number.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== Specialist and graduate training === Beginning in 1972, the [[medical school]] through a variety of arrangements for postgraduate education, has trained specialists for national needs. Originally, this was carried out through the [[Royal College of Physicians|Royal College]]<nowiki/>s of the [[United Kingdom]], later the West African Postgraduate Medical College and now the Ghana College of Physicians and Surgeons.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" /> The [[Medical School]] has two programs: the undergraduate [[MB ChB|MBChB]] program for students from the [[Secondary School]], and the Graduate Entry Medical Program for Graduate students with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree.<ref name=":2" /> It has also runs the Graduate Entrance Medical Programme (GEMP) for people who did [[Bachelor Degree]]s<ref name=":3" /> in the natural sciences, applied sciences, engineering but not [[medicine]]
=== Link to other health-related institutions === The UGMS was instrumental in the establishment of other Ghanaian and African medical schools. In 1970s, the first two batches from the [[College of Health Sciences (KNUST)|School of Medical Sciences]], [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]], completed their training at [[Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital|Korle-Bu]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In the 1990s and 2000s, before the Tamale hospital was upgraded to ta teaching hospital, the UGMS hosted students from the School of Medicine and Health Sciences, [[University for Development Studies]] (UDS) for pre- and para-clinical and full clinical training leading to the earning of UDS degrees. Professors from the UGMS also go to the UDS from time to time to aid in teaching. A College Council that governs the institution replaced the Executive Council.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The University of Ghana Dental School started in 1974 under the aegis of the UGMS, before attaining full faculty status in 1992.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The ''Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research'' was founded in 1979 in partnership with the UGMS.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1994, the Ghanaian [[Ministry of Health (Ghana)|Ministry of Health]] (MoH) authorised a new course: the ''Diploma in Medical Laboratory Technology'' to train laboratory technicians for the country’s hospitals.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In the same year, the MoH collaborated with the UGMS to establish a ''School of Public Health'' that would awarded postgraduate degrees in public health, epidemiology and related fields.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1998, the School of Allied Health Science was started for the training of laboratory scientists, physiotherapists, radiographers, medical and dental technologists and other allied health professionals.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The UGMS was the progenitor of the idea to merge all the health-related schools of the University of Ghana into the first constituent college of the university - the College of Health Sciences. Upon the establishment of the College of Health Sciences in 1999, the UGMS, together with five other medical schools became a constituent college.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The UGMS played a critical role in the curriculum development for the establishment of the University of Cape Coast Medical School.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" />
== Recent developments == With financial assistance from the [[Government of Israel|Israeli government,]] a state-of-the-art University Teaching Hospital on the campus of the University of Ghana, Legon was recently completed and the UGMS is in the process expanding infrastructure and access to medical education. The university has in recent years started a school of [[Biomedical sciences|biomedical science]]<nowiki/>s and [[Biomedical engineering|engineering]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The UGMS plans to construct simulated laboratories to meet increased demand while making use of peripheral hospitals for clinical training.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In the future, the medical school plans to introduce distance learning programmes for certain disciplines.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Investment in the school’s research portfolio in the biomedical sciences is a top priority for the university’s medical school. International student tuition is the main source of the school’s internally–generated funds (IGFs).<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" />
== Past Deans == *[[Charles Odamtten Easmon]] * S. R. A. Dodu * H. H. Phillips * F. N. L. Engmann * E. Q. Archampong * S. K. Owusu * A. S. Ayettey * [[Clifford Nii Boi Tagoe]] * Aaron L. Lawson

Badoe]], surgery *[[Charles Odamtten Easmon]], surgery *[[Emmanuel Evans-Anfom]], anatomy *[[Kwabena Frimpong-Boateng]], cardiothoracic surgery *[[Susan Ofori-Atta]], paediatrics * [[Fred T. Sai]], community health and social medicine *[[Clifford Nii Boi Tagoe]], anatomy

Clerk]], [[psychiatrist]] and [[sleep medicine]] specialist; Director, [[Stanford University Medical Center|Stanford Center for Sleep Sciences and Medicine]]| (1990 – 1998)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sleepmedicineservice.com/meetourspecialist.html|title=:: Sleep Medicine Services ::|website=www.sleepmedicineservice.com|access-date=2018-06-26|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160125073055/http://sleepmedicineservice.com/meetourspecialist.html|archivedate=2016-01-25|df=}}</ref>

The '''Warne Report'''<ref>{{ISBN|0-11-752749-1}}, Crown copyright.</ref> was published by the United Kingdom Government in 1993. It was referred to in a government consultation paper on [[Reform of Architects Registration]] dated 19 July 1994. Eventually, certain changes to the Architects Registration Acts were enacted in 1996 which now have effect under the [[Architects Act 1997]].
== Overview ==
The Warne Report had been drawn up by (Ernest) John (David) Warne, CB. He had been secretary to the [[Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales]] from 1982 to 1990. After graduating BA in the [[University of London]] he had entered the [[Civil Service (United Kingdom)|Civil Service]], and after a series of promotions and transfers (detailed in ''[[Who's Who (UK)|Who's Who]]'') he had become an Under-Secretary in the [[Department of Industry]], and eventually Deputy Director-General of the [[Office of Fair Trading]], 1979-1982. Mr Warne summarised the conclusion of his report as follows:
* "'''My main recommendation is that the protection of title 'architect' should be abolished and [[ARCUK]] disbanded''', I believe that this will help modify some of the outmoded distinctions and attitudes which inhibit change within the [[construction industry]]. It should also help the efforts being made in the architectural profession to improve the relevance of education and training to the business world in which architects must operate. Although the loss of the [[monopoly]] use of the title '[[architect]]' (but not the term '[[chartered architect]]') will be unwelcome to many in the [[profession]], I suggest that time will show that the protection of title has been largely irrelevant to the standing of the architectural profession or to the [[public interest]]..."
== See also ==
* The [[Architects (Registration) Acts, 1931 to 1938]]. * [[Registration of architects in the United Kingdom]] * {{Wikipedia books link| Registration of Architects in the United Kingdom}}

Accra
Ghana | superintendent = | principal = Mr. Kodja Edoh | faculty = Information & Communication Technology | grades = | campus_type = | nickname = wisak | newspaper = | affiliations = [[City and Guilds of London Institute]] | website = {{URL|www.wisakinstitute.com}} | footnotes = | enrollment = | colors = {{Color box|teal|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|white|border=darkgray}} teal and white | feeders = }} '''Wisak College of Technology''' (abbreviated '''Wisak'''The College itself only spells its short form as "Wisak"; other spellings such as "Wi sak" [http://{{URL|www.wisakinstitute.com}} and "college". The Institute is also occasionally referred to as "WI-SAK", most notably in its [[wisak]],n.) is a private Diploma-granting College which was established in 2003 in the Greater [[Accra]] region in [[Ghana]]. It is registered under the Ghana Education Service, [[Ministry of Education (Ghana)]] and also approved by City and Guilds of London institute in the UK. {{Cite web|url=http://www.cityandguilds.com|title=cityandguilds|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Over 3000 students and ICT Professionals has been trained in Wisak college since 2003 it was formed.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Ministry of Education (Ghana)]] [[Category:Education in Ghana]]
